loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
Maribel tiene 37 años, vive con su pareja y padre de sus tres hijos en su casa propia, la cual construyó hace 4 y está hecha a base de madera. 

Ella es profesora en un colegio de su localidad, pero desde hace 5 años también vende ropa. Se inicio en este negocio vendiendo ropa interior en las reuniones de sus familiares y amigos, gracias al capital que le brindó su esposo. A pesar que a veces corre el riesgo de ser asaltada cuando va de compras sola, eso no le amilana, ya que lo que más le gusta es el comercio y su mayor preocupación es atender a sus clientes oportunamente, inclusive en sus mismos domicilios.  En adelante, quiere tener una tienda de ropa en su casa para mejorar el nivel de vida de su familia.

Este es su catorceavo crédito con MFP, donde se compromete a pagar cada una de sus cuotas oportunamente, para que pueda contar con posteriores préstamos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará más prendas para cubrir los pedidos de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Maribel, 37, lives with her life partner and father of her three children in her own, wood house that she built 4 years ago. She is a teacher at a local school but has also sold clothing for the past 5 years. She started off in this business selling underwear at social gatherings with her family and friends thanks to initial capital that her husband gave her. Despite sometimes running the risk of being robbed when she’s out shopping alone, that doesn’t discourage her. What she likes best about her work is the commerce and her greatest worry is being able to take care of her customers properly, sometimes even going to their own homes. In the future, she’d like to have a clothing store in her house so that she can improve her family’s standard of living. This is her 14th loan with MFP and she pledges to repay on time so that she can qualify for future loans. She will use the funds to buy more articles of clothing to fill pending orders from her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.es:
Verónica tiene 40 años, está casada y vive con su esposo en la casa de su madre, en un populoso barrio en el cono sur de la ciudad de Lima.

Después de trabajar por 12 años en la panadería con su esposo, Verónica emprendió su propio negocio; la venta de productos de belleza. Lleva dos años en esta actividad y le está yendo muy bien, es por ello que no escatima en usar todas sus energías caminando por las zonas áridas de su localidad bajo el intenso sol con el fin de buscar a sus clientes. 
En las épocas de otoño e invierno también vende porciones de queque, pues en esa época son muy demandados estos bocaditos. Realizar estas dos actividades es mucho más rentable,  ya que con esas ganancias viene mejorando el acabado del espacio donde vive. Su mayor anhelo para el futuro es proveerse con más productos de belleza para satisfacer a todos sus clientes.

Este es su catorceavo préstamo con MFP, por lo que se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas en las fechas establecidas. Asimismo, participa en armonía con sus compañeras porque desea seguir contando con posteriores créditos, por ser indispensables para su negocio.

Con el dinero que solicita comprará más productos de belleza, así como los ingredientes de pastelería, porque el verano ya está terminando.
texts.en:
Verónica, 40, is married and lives with her husband in her mother’s home, located in a densely populated neighborhood in the south of Lima. After having worked in her husband’s bakery for 12 years, Verónica started her own business: beauty products sales. She has been in this line of work for two years and is doing very well. For this reason, she spares no effort in using all her energy to walk through the arid areas of her neighborhood, under the intense heat of the sun, to seek out customers. During fall and winter she also sells cake slices because these snacks are very popular that time of year. To do both activities is quite profitable and the profits have helped her to make improvements to her living space. Her greatest wish for the future is to stock up more beauty products so that she can have all she needs to meet customer demands. This is her 14th loan with MFP and she pledges to repay in a timely fashion. In addition, she participates harmoniously with her fellow group members because she wants to have access to future loans because they are indispensable to her business. She will use the requested funds to buy more beauty products as well as ingredients for her pastries because summer is ending.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products and baking ingredients.

loans.name: Leaso

texts.en:
Leaso V. is 38 and married with 3 children (ages 6 - 11).  She owns a business venture, 0.  Leaso has 3 years of experience in this business.  Leaso needs a loan of WST $1250 to purchase game prizes.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Leaso joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Leaso's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase game prizes

loans.name: María Dominga

texts.es: La señora A. L., se dedica a la administración de su pulpería personalmente, tiene dos hijos, uno mayor de edad y uno menor, tiene más de 30 años de tener su negocio, el que le ha permitido obtener sus ingresos para el sustento de su hogar, con este préstamo invertirá en productos como granos básicos para abastecer su negocio y ofrecer a sus clientes, para obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Mrs. A. L. manages her own grocery store. She has two children. One is an adult and the other one a minor. She has been working in her grocery store for more than 30 years and been able to make profits to maintain her home. With this loan she plans to invest in products such as basic grains to supply her business and offer them to her clients to make greater profits.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of basic grains

Faafiu needs a loan of WST $1700 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Faafiu joined SPBD.This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Faafiu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

loans.name: Rosario Amparo

texts.es: La Sra. Rosario tiene 48 años D. edad tiene 4 hijos do D. ellos  mayores D. edad, y dos en edad escolar, ella es viuda, vive en casa propia D. material noble recientemente construida, ya que fue afectada por el terremoto, ella actualmente se esta dedicando a la venta D. productos D. limpieza en el mercado Arenales como ambulante, adicional a eso  prestando servcios D. costuras, ella tiene muchos sueños y objetivos uno D. ellos es poner un negocio propio en su casa. Con el dinero que solicita invertira en capaital D. trabajo para su negocio.
texts.en:
Rosario, 48, has four children, two of whom are adults and two still in school. She is a widow and lives in her own, recently built with substantial materials (because it was damaged by the earthquake), home. She sells home cleaning supplies in the Arenales market; she also works as a seamstress. She has many dreams and goals in life, one of which is to set up her own business in her home. She will use the funds to buy more stock items.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy home cleaning supplies.

The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

loans.name: Esperanza Marcelina

texts.es: La señora Bogorge A., es una señora trabajadora que le ha gustado trabajar desde joven, para ser independiente, con las utilidades de su negocio ha logrado educar a sus hijos y mantener su hogar, con el préstamo compra gaseosas y frutas para los refrescos naturales que realiza, para mejorar su negocio y obtener mayores utilidades, para el sustento de sus hogar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bogorge A. is a hard-working woman who has enjoyed working from a very early age in order to be independent. She has used profits from her business to educate her children and support her household. She will use the funds to buy soft-drinks and fruits for natural beverages that she makes in order to improve her business and earn higher profits to support her household.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soft-drinks and fruits for beverages.

loans.name: Emeritiana

texts.en:
Emeritiana L. is 28 and married with 1 child (1 year-old).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Emeritiana has 3 years of experience in this business.  Emeritiana needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $146 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Emeritiana joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Emeritiana's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana T. is from the village of Puntod. She is 52 years old. Juana is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Juana owns & operates a business planting & harvesting rice for sale. Juana has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Juana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Juana is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Juana from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina V.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for sale. She is 39 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Tipolo. Gina has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2001, Gina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to to purchase livestock to raise and sell. Gina is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 15th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Alona

texts.en: Alona G. is from the village of Aloran. She is 33 years old. Alona is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Alona owns and operates a snack-vending business, making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Alona has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Alona joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alona has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Alona is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Alona from PMPC, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory  and working capital

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine E. is from the village of Dullan. She is 52 years old. Josephine is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a fish-vending business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling ocean fish caught by her husband. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2000, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC, a Kiva partner. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. This will be the 15th loan taken out by Josephine from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita L. is from the village of Upper Loboc. She is 50 years old. Lolita is married and has an adult child. To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a "lechon" (roasted pig) business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing "lechon" to local community members. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippine pesos a month for this activity. In 2009, Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC, a Kiva partner. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Lolita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Daniel Enrique

texts.es:
Daniel 26 años de edad, es soltero, vive con sus padres en su vivienda. El se inicio 
en el negocio de venta de alimentos balanceados para aves en un mercado de la 
localidad, primero con un capital pequeño producto de ahorros obtenidos por sus 
trabajos ya que es de profesión veterinario, en la actualidad ha implementado otra 
tienda en la tinguiña, se incrementado el negocio con mucho esfuerzo. El atiende el 
negocio de manera muy calida y amable ya que la gran mayoría de sus clientes son 
personas de la campiña, solicita el crédito para invertir en mercadería y de  esta 
manera incrementar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Daniel, age 26, is single and lives at home with his parents. He started his business for the sale of specially balanced bird feed in a town market, beginning with a small amount of capital from savings from his job as a veterinarian. Currently, he has opened another shop in Tinguiña, and he has grown his business with a lot of effort. He tends his shop and his his countryside clients in a very warm and friendly manner. He is requesting this loan in order to invest in more merchandise and increase his income as a result.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Merchlewitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora J. is from the village of Panaon. She is 48 years-old and she is married and she have 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Leonora owns and operates a "sari-sari" (general) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for this activity.

In 2009, Leonora joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the ??? loan taken out by Leonora from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita M. is from the village of Culpan. She is 43 years-old and married with six adult children. To make a living, Conchita owns and operates a "sari-sari" (general) store.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Conchita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for this activity.

In 2009, Conchita joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Conchita has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Conchita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Conchita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Crisologia

texts.en:
Crisologia has a business catching crabs. She started this business in 1992. She has five children and her eldest is 21 years-old. One of her dreams is to have her children finish their schooling. 

She is requesting a loan of 19,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to have additional capital for her business. What she likes in CEVI is that the loans have low interest and there are only 20 weeks of repayment.

loans.use: To provide additional capital.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza, 47, sells crab traps for fishing to earn a living. Her business helps a great deal towards sending her children to school. She wishes to for them to complete their studies soon. She has four children, her eldest is 20 years-old. 

She joined Kiva Partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to partner with her business. Currently she is requesting a loan of 25,000 to continually support her business. This is a big help for her to sustain her business and family.

loans.use: To support her business.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina, 60, is the mother of eight children. She supports her children by selling crab traps in her community. She started this business back in 1975. This is the only way she can support her family. She sought help from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in order to have additional capital for her business. She has asked for a loan of 6,000 Php. This will be useful to improve her business and the low interest rate will be less of a burden to pay.

loans.use: To provide additional capital.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en: Arlene C., 39 years-old, is from Veruela Agusan Del Sur. She has a farm, which she hopes can provide her family their daily needs. She hopes to develop her livelihood more to be able to improve the family economic situation.  She is asking for a loan of Php 5,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en: 50 years old, Avelina L. doesn’t know anymore how will she budget their small income. Her husband works as a farmer and she is helping her husband maintain the rice field. She is currently preparing her farm for planting and this is why she needs help to be able to improve the harvest. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 5,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers, and pay the rental of the farm equipment.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and rent farm equipment.

loans.name: Clementa

texts.en: Clementa M. has been married for 27-years. She has four children and she grows rice in Veruela Agusan Del Sur. The income which she gets from growing rice has helped her family a lot to buy food and other basic needs. Now, she has a small problem financing her rice farm so she is applying for a loan of Php 5,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc in order to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en: Editha B., 48 years-old, owns a small rice farm. Aside from the farm, she also has a small piggery and sari-sari (general) store. These help her buy the things which her family needs such as food, clothes and other basic necessities. She says that, if she doesn't work hard on her farm, she won't be able to support her family. Now, she is having difficulty in maintaining her one-hectare farm because of financial constraints in the family. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 5,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa, 48, sells charcoal to have an income for her family. Her ambition is for her children to achieve their dreams. She supports six children in the family. Since 2004, she has partnered her business with Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. 

Currently she is asking for a loan of 15,000 to buy more stocks of charcoal. She likes CEVI loans because of the low interest rates and short weeks of repayments.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en: Gemma P. a 36-year-old rice farmer has three children. Because her eldest child is 13 years old, she has been quite worried how to manage their income when her child starts going to college soon. She would like to grow her rice farm business. Now she has been busy preparing it for the next planting. However, she said, she still needs additional money to complete the process. She thinks of applying for a loan of PHP 5,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita is a rice farmer in Talibon, Bohol. She needs farm inputs to operate her rice field. But she lacks capital. That's why she sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. requesting a loan of 21,000 PHP. This loan will enable her to provide the supplies needed for her farm. Lolita wishes her family good health and to be able to eat their meals everyday. Rice farming is the only way she can provide the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia owns a rice field.  She’s 43 years old and has a rice farming business in Talibon, Bohol.  She started her business a long time ago.  With the income she receives from her farm, she can sustain the needs of her family.  

Lucia joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to take a loan for her farm.  She requested an amount of 16,000 PHP as additional capital to finance her business.  With this amount, she can buy fertilizer, seeds, and other farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina F. manages a small rice field. She has four children; the eldest is 11 years old. Her husband is a farmer and they work together to improve their harvest to support their children more. Now, the family is preparing the farm for another planting. They need additional money to buy all the farming materials. She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 5,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites, 36, a rice farmer from Talibon, Bohol.  She manages a rice field.  She supports her family; she has two children. She hopes to let her children finish their studies. She works hard in order to have a good harvest. She wants to live a good life and has fear of God.

She is limited in her capital, which is why she joined in Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to avail a loan.  She’s requesting 13,000 PHP to support her business by buying seeds and farm materials.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Nurbubu's Group

texts.ru:
Люди по – разному верят в приход успеха в их жизнь. Некоторые полагают, что успех – это везение, счастливая судьба  и нечто предписанное и не зависящее от самого человека явление. Другая же группа людей верит, что хоть от судьбы никуда не уйдёшь, однако сама судьба предоставляет нам выбор жить, так или иначе. И успех наш зависит от конкретных усилий и стараний, а не от везения. Такого мнения придерживаются и герои нашей истории. Нурбубу Макеева– лидер данной группы. У Нурбубу трое детей. Старшая дочь замужем. Средний сын учится на втором курсе в Аграрном университете, а самая младшая дочь учится в средней школе. Положение в селе довольно тяжёлое, учитывая безработицу и массовый отток населения в города. Однако Нурбубу вместе с мужем попытались всё - таки попытать счастье в родном краю. Они купили корову, откормили и перепродали за десять тысяч сомов ($200). На эти деньги они обратно закупили скот, только теперь овец и с тех пор это стало основным их занятием. Перепродажа скота позволила им отправить дочь на обучение в Бишкек, а в дальнейшем приготовить ей приданое. Сейчас их доход составляет около пяти тысяч ($130) сомов в месяц. Муж являясь членом фермерского хозяйства, активно помогает Нурбубу ухаживать за скотом. Сейчас, Нурбубу нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить четырёх баранов для откорма. 

У Нурбубу три партнёра по группе:

Эдилу Аскарбек – уулу двадцать один год. Он женат. Его супруга работает учительницей. У Эдила есть сын, которому всего десять месяцев. Эдил работает главным инспектором в районной архитектуре. Эдил решил обратиться за кредитом, чтобы закупить ГСМ для сельскохозяйственных работ. 

Нурисе Матсаевой тридцать лет. Муж Нурисы – член фермерского хозяйства. Нуриса воспитывает троих детей. Помимо них с ними также живут свекровь и свекор Нурисы. Дочь учится в третьем классе, средний сын учится во втором классе, а младшая дочь пока дома. Нуриса работает медсестрой. Нурисе нужен кредит, чтобы купить стиральную машину. 

Нурзаде Кожомкуловой тридцать один год. У Нурзады двое детей. Старший сын уже пошёл в школу. А также вместе с Нурзадой живёт и её свекровь. Чтобы прокормить семью Нурзада продаёт ГСМ, а её муж занимается фермерством. Нурзада начала торговлю с помощью кредита, который она получила полтора года назад. Сейчас она вновь нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить сто литров ГСМ.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
People have different beliefs in how success comes into their lives. Some believe that success is luck, a lucky fate and something prescribed, a phenomenon which is not in the person's power. Another group of people believes that though you cannot escape from fate however the fate itself gives us a choice in how we want to live. And our success depends on actual efforts and diligence rather than luck. This is the opinion which belongs to the characters of our story. Nurbubu M. is a leader of this group. Nurbubu has three children. Her oldest daughter is married. Her middle son is in his sophomore year in the Agrarian university, and her youngest daughter goes to secondary school. The conditions in the village are very difficult considering unemployment and a mass exodus of the population into the cities. But Nurbubu and her husband still tried to find happiness in their homeland. They bought a cow, fed it and resold for ten thousand soms ($200US). The used this money to buy cattle, but this time sheep and since then it has become their main business. Reselling of the cattle has allowed them to send their daughter to study in Bishkek and to prepare her dowry later on. At this time their income is around five thousand soms ($130) a month. Her husband is a member of the farmer's union and is actively helping Nurbubu to take care of the cattle. Right now Nurbubu needs a loan to buy four rams for feeding. Nurbubu has three partners in the group: Edil A.-U. is 21 years old. He is married. His wife works as a teacher. Edil has a son who is only ten months old. Edil works as a head inspector in the regional architectural association. He has decided to ask for a loan to buy GSM (fuel and oil for machinery) for agricultural work. Nurisa M. is thirty years old. Nurisa's husband is a member of the farmer's union. Nurisa is raising three children. Nurisa's parents-in-law also live together with her family. Her daughter is in third grade and middle son is in the second grade, her youngest daughter is staying at home. Nurisa works as a nurse. She needs a loan to buy a washing machine. Nurzada K. is thirty one years old. Nurzada has two children. Her oldest son goes to school. Her mother-in-law also lives with Nurzada. To feed the entire family Nurzada sells GSM (fuel and oil for machinery equipment) and her husband is in farming. Nurzada has started selling with a loan which she received a year and a half ago. Right now she again needs a loan to buy 100 liters of fuel and oil.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy four sheep for feeding and resale

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith, 33 years old, is a mother of two children. Her eldest child is only five and currently excited to go to pre-school. She is a farmer and is tilling a small rice field. The income she makes from the farm really helped her family buy food, clothing and other basic needs.

She would like to apply for a loan of 5,000 PHP at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina, 32, has a business selling a variety of food in her neighborhood. She also has a fishing business. She has four children in her family and she hopes they will graduate from their studies someday.

Regina is now on her seventh loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., with a loan request of 10,000 PHP. This loan will help improve her fishing business and provide the needs of her family.

loans.use: For food ingredients and fishing

loans.name: Mairam's Group

texts.en: There is a proverb that says an empty cart rumbles more than a packed one. A lot of people tend to teach others how to settle things and organize one's own life. Well, there are a lot less people who take substantial steps towards accomplishing their aims rather than just nattering on about it. Mairam O. is a leader of this group. She is sixty-one years old. Mairam has raised six children. Her eldest son is forty and her youngest son is twenty-four years old. Having had this many children, who are now grownups and already have their own families and earn their own livelihoods, Mairam could now excuse herself from any work. But it is not in her nature to be a couch potato and occupy herself with idleness. Instead, she makes handicrafts and sells them to foreign customers. First she presented her works to one foreign company and made a contract with them to make handicrafts for them. She also worked as a consultant. Recently, she has secured a big order for handicrafts and now is working on it. Mairam has even gotten her daughter involved in this business, to prepare the order in time. Now, Mairam needs a loan to buy materials for making handicrafts. Mairam’s partners are: Kerez A., 61, is a manufacturer of national articles. Her husband is officially retired but he works part time as a technician. Kerez and her husband have raised six children. Kerez needs a loan to buy materials. Burul J., 33, is single. She lives with her mother and produces national articles. Her sisters help her buy materials. Burul wants to obtain this loan buy materials for making articles. Svetkul A., 56, is a mother of four children. Svetkul runs a non-government organization “Altyn Kol”, which promotes handicrafts. Svetkul needs a loan to purchase materials. Upol M., 55, is a widow. She has four children. She is also a member of “Altyn Kol”. Upol is occupied with manufacturing national articles as well as works as an accountant. She hopes to obtain this loan to purchase materials. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy materials for making handicrafts

loans.name: Ainakul's Group

texts.en:
Ainakul S. is the leader of this group. Her husband’s daily routine starts early in the morning, with taking the manure out of the shed, giving water to the cows and milking the cows. As any person living in a village area, she runs a small household and even though they live in the area which is known for its harsh winters, they are perfectly used to local weather conditions. 

Ainakul is a mother of three children. All the children go to school. Her eldest son is fifteen. After school, he helps his parents look after the cattle. However, Ainakul tries not to burden her children with anything concerning housework as she believes that her children should be spared of all that to have more free time for studies. Ainakul is forty-five years old and feels herself in sufficiently good health and does not feel tiredness until evening. Now they are feeding a calf which they bought for $230. Ainakul’s dream is to give her children good education, help them get on their feet and improve her family’s living conditions. Her husband is currently a member of a farm and also works as a procurement manager of a high school. Now Ainakul needs a loan to buy four sheep for feeding and resale. 

Ainakul’s partners are: 

Burul S., 57, is the wife of a school worker. She has a sixteen-year-old daughter. Burul is busy with cattle that they keep at home. Burul has applied for this loan to buy more cattle. 

Nazgul A., 34, is the wife of a computer science and math teacher. Nazgul has three little children and currently does not work as she has to look after the kids. Now they keep three calves and need a loan to buy some sheep. 

Aibek K., 23, is married. His wife goes to college, and Aibek has to provide for both of them. Aibek works at school and wants to start a new business as an additional source of income. He hopes to obtain this loan and buy sheep for feeding. His wife will help him. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy four sheep for feeding and resale

loans.name: Terisita

texts.en:
51-year-old Terisita has been in the fishing business since 1990. She wants a loan to provide the materials she needs in her business. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and currently she is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP.

Terisita has seven children and she wants them to be educated. She hopes to provide them with school supplies and to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fishing supplies

loans.name: Loenila

texts.en: Leonila R., 49 years old, is a farmer and also a vendor in Trento Agusan del Sur. She is doing this to support the needs of her two children. She is a tenant on a two-hectare rice field. She helps her husband manage their farm so that they will have an abundant harvest to feed their family. She dreamed of having a farm someday, so she is doing her best to be able to prosper through an improved harvest. She would like to apply for a loan of 5,000 PHP at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Cholpon's Group

texts.en:
The lives of ordinary people cease to be ordinary once these seemingly ordinary people change the way they think and perceive reality. At this very moment it is very important that they are able to find the necessary support to implement their ideas into their lives. 

Cholpon S. is the leader of this group. She is forty-six years old. Cholpon and her husband have three wonderful children. Their only aim now is to give their children a proper education and help them get on their feet and bring their own dreams into reality. While their children are growing up, Cholpon and her husband are doing their best to provide them with all necessary things, whether it is food, clothes or school supplies, so that their children do not feel the need for anything. The elder daughters are college students and the younger daughter goes to school.

Cholpon’s husband is a school teacher, and he and Cholpon keep some cattle and trade them on weekends. Cholpon has applied for this loan because she hopes to buy a calf for feeding and resale. Their aim is to increase the total population of their livestock in a short time. 

Cholpon’s partners: 

Ermekgul A., 29, has three children. Her husband is in charge of water distribution at the fields. Ermekgul stays at home with the children. She hopes to obtain this loan to buy sheep. 

Sapina K., 57, has five children. She and her husband are retired and their children are grown and married. Sapina hopes to obtain this loan to buy sheep. 

Syinagul T., 54, is a mother of five children. She and her husband keep some cattle and their children help them. Syinagul has applied for this loan to buy two sheep for feeding and resale. 

Gulaida R., 39, is the wife of a tractor driver. She has four children. Two of her children go to school. To provide for the family her husband also keeps some cattle. Gulaida hopes to obtain this loan to buy a calf. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy a calf for feeding and resale

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Having ten children in the family requires more courage of Leonila. With her fishing business, she is able to provide for them. She hopes to educate them and to be physically healthy. With her loan through Community Economic Ventures, Inc., she wants to make each payment on time.

Leonila, 48, is currently requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP.  This loan will help her buy an engine for her boat and some crab traps.

loans.use: To buy an engine for her boat and some crab traps

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.ru:
На ровном месте ничего не строиться. Герои этой истории на примере собственной жизни показывают, что это именно значит. Дамира Алдаярова– лидер группы. Она вместе с семьёй проживает в с. Тюп, что находится на берегу прекрасного озера Ыссык – Куль (в переводе с кыргызского языка: горячая вода). Дамире пятьдесят лет. Вместе с мужем она вырастила двоих сыновей. Сейчас  у них даже есть один внук. Муж Дамиры и её два сына занимаются домашним хозяйством. У них имеется скот, и дети заготавливают для него корм. Помимо этого, с весны вся семья также занимается земледелием. Дамира, же дома смотрит за коровой и продаёт молоко. Иногда им удаётся подзаработать от перепродажи скота. К примеру, прошлой весной, они купили двух ягнят по полторы тысячи сомов  ($35) и перепродали их по две с половиной тысячи сомов ($55) осенью. От одной продажи молока, им удаётся заработать до тысячи сомов ($22) в месяц. Таким образом, у них складывается довольно богатый спектр занятий, включающий в себя и земледелие, и животноводство, и торговлю. Сейчас Дамира хочет купить четырёх ягнят, и одного бычка для откорма, чтобы затем перепродать осенью. Она надеется получить этот кредит и осуществить задуманное. В дальнейшем, Дамира и её семья планируют увеличить пахотные земли с пяти до десяти гектаров, что в свою очередь должно принести им в два раза больше урожая, чем раньше. 

Партнёры Дамиры по группе – её односельчане:

Роза Тойгонбаева, вдова и мать троих сыновей. Роза, имеет кое – какую живность. Дети летом помогают заготовить корм. С апреля месяца, Роза планирует продавать молоко. Одна из её коров скоро отелится. Роза обратилась за кредитом, с целью закупить ягнят для откорма.

Рапия Балтабаева– вдода и мать четверых детей. Сын живёт вместе с ней и помогает по хозяйству. Дочери учатся в школе. Рапия ежедневно сдаёт по шесть литров молока и готовит корм для скота. Продажа молока приносит ей ежемесячно по полтора тысячи сомов. Сейчас Рапие нужен кредит, чтобы купить корову для откорма. 

Тологон Турсумбаевой, пятьдесят четыре года. У Тологон один сын. Тологон продаёт молоко по шесть литров, а сын готовит сельскохозяйственную технику для полевых работ. Тологон надеется получить кредит, с помощью которого, она планирует закупить скот и таким образом увеличить поголовье. Недавно, она уже продала кобылу, и купила корову и овец.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Damir A. is the leader of the group. She and her family live in Tup, which is located on the shores of beautiful Lake Issyk-Kul. Damir is married, fifty years old with two sons. They have cattle, and the children help them to store food. In addition, since the spring the family is also farming. Damir has one milk cow to produce milk and earns extra income from the sale of livestock. For example, last spring, they bought two lambs for a half thousand soms ($35) and resold them for two and a half thousand soms ($55) in the autumn. From a single sale of milk, they are able to earn up to a thousand soms ($22) per month. They have a rather wide range of occupations, which includes agriculture, livestock, and trade. Damir now wants to buy four lambs and one calf for fattening, to then resell in the fall. She hopes to get the loan and to realize her plans. In the future, Damir and her family are planning to increase arable land from five to ten hectares, which in turn should bring them in twice the yield than before.

Damir’s Partners live in the same village:

Roza T. is a widow with three sons. Rose has some livestock. Her children help in the summer to procure forage. Since April, Rose plans to sell milk. One of her cows will calve soon. Rose is asking for a loan, to purchase lambs for fattening.

Rapiya B. is a widow and mother of four children. Her son helps her with the business while her daughters study in school. Rapiya’s cows produces six liters of milk. Milk sales earns her a monthly one and a half thousand soms. She is asking for a loan to buy a cow for fattening.

Tologon T. is fifty-four years old with one son. Tologon sells six liters of milk daily and her son is a farm equipment mechanic. Tologon hopes to get a loan with which she plans to purchase cattle, and increase the stock. Recently, she already sold a mare, and bought a cow and sheep.

Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase land livestock

loans.name: Virgilio

texts.en:
Virgilio is a 62-year-old fisherman from Talibon, Bohol. He catches fish to lift up his family towards success. He is married to Erlinda and has four children. He has 50 years experience in fishing. He wants to live a simple life, to have food for his family to eat and to pay his debts.

He joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in 2003 and finds it helpful for his business. He is currently asking for a loan of 25,000 PHP to provide more fishing supplies.

loans.use: To buy fishing supplies

loans.name: Bekishkan's Group

texts.ru:
Бекишкан Байкубатова– лидер группы. Ей сорок шесть. У Бекишкан и её мужа трое детей. Муж Бекишкан и старший сын, которому двадцать пять лет, работают на арендованном микроавтобусе. Три года назад Бекишкан закупила семенной картофель на общие семейные сбережения. Теперь Бекишкан с остальными детьми сажают картофель, и занимаются прополкой, сбором урожай и его продажей. Младшая дочь учиться в школе, в десятом классе. Она и её средний брат активно помогают маме выращивать картофель. Эта работа требует огромного терпения и трудолюбия, чего Бекишкан с её детьми не занимать. Младшая дочь прекрасно совмещает учёбу с домашним семейным бизнесом, что уже является для неё хорошим воспитанием в себе деловых качеств, которые ей пригодятся в дальнейшей взрослой жизни. Сейчас ежемесячный доход от продажи картофеля составляет всего чуть больше чем две с половиной тысяч сомов ($55). Это небольшой доход, но учитывая, что в самом начале, ещё три года назад, они вложили всего около двух тысяч сомов ($50) в закупку этого картофеля, а также то, что сезон продажи картофеля начнётся осенью, то можно считать, что всё ещё впереди. Сейчас у Бекишкан есть планы дальше развивать свой картофельный бизнес. Ещё бы, ведь у Бекишкан есть видение того, как дальше двигаться.  Бекишкан хочет получить кредит и купить семенной картофель сорта «Мандиал», а также расширить площадь посева. 

Партнёры Бекишкан по группе:

Кулукан Куронкеевой пятьдесят два года. Муж Кулукан – временно безработный. У Кулукан есть сын, которому двадцать три года. Он студент одного из столичных ВУЗов. Сама Кулукан печёт лепёшки и разносит по магазинам. Сейчас ей нужен кредит для того, чтобы купить ГСМ на весенние полевые работы. 

Эркин Акматовой шестьдесят три года. Сын Эркин и её муж разводят овец. Сама Эркин находится дома и занята домашним хозяйством и продажей молока. От одной продажи молока они зарабатывают четыре с половиной тысяч сомов в месяц. Эркин обратилась за кредитом, так как хочет закупить ещё овец на откорм. 


Наметжану Асранову тридцать пять лет. Жена Наметжана  - домохозяйка и занимается домашними хлопотами. Наметжан откармливает и продаёт овец. Ранее он занимался крупно – рогатым скотом, но вот уже на протяжении десяти лет занимается только овцами. Наметжан надеется получить кредит и купить овец на откорм и дальнейшей перепродажи на скотном рынке.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Bekishkan B. is the group leader, forty-six years old, married with four children. Bekishkan’s husband and eldest son, who is twenty-five years old, rent minivans for deliveries. Three years ago, Bekishkan purchased seed potatoes. Bekishkan, along with her children, are growing potatoes for sale. The youngest daughter is in the tenth grade. She and her middle brother, are helping their mother. Their current monthly income from the sale of potatoes is slightly more than two and a half thousand soms ($55). It is a small income, but considering that at the very beginning, three years ago, they invested a total of about two thousand soms ($50) in the purchase of potatoes, as well as the fact that the potato season sales begin in the fall, we can assume that they will make a profit. Now, Bekishkan has plans to further develop her potato business. Bekishkan wants to get a loan and buy potato seed varieties called "Mundial", as well as to increase the acreage.

Bekishkan’s Partners for the group:

Kulukan K. is fifty-two years old and her husband is unemployed. Her son is a twenty-three year old student. Kulukan bakes flat breads and delivers to the shops. Now she wants a loan to buy equipment for spring field work.

Erkin A. is sixty-three years old and her son and husband breed of sheep. Erkin is a homemaker and sells milk. Their milk sales bring in four and a half thousand soms per month. Erkin is asking for a loan because she wants to buy another sheep for fattening.

Nametjan A. is thirty-five years old and married. Ten years ago, he was involved in raising cattle, but now for the past ten years, he raises and sells only sheep. Nametjan hopes to get a loan to buy a sheep for fattening to increase his sales.

Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Agriculture and livestock purchases

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia L., 49 years old, is a rice farmer. Her husband works on their farm and she is helping him to have an abundant harvest. She has six children and she wants to provide them with all their needs. The income she makes from her farm is really helpful in ensuring the supply of food in their family.

Lilia would really like to grow her harvest but needs a small amount of money to buy all the farming necessities like fertilizer and farm supplies. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 5,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will mean an increased harvest.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
Rubelyn, 30, sells fish in Talibon, Bohol. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 Php to have additional capital for her business. She buys fish directly from the fishermen and sells to the market with a mark up. She does this to earn a living and support her family.

Rubelyn has two children and wants them to be in school. She is thankful, as a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to have an opportunity to help her business grow.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita B. is a 66 year-old married woman who supports her family by buying and selling nipa (leaves used for roofing of homes). She lives in Sitio Turil, Brgy Daan Banua, Ilog, Negros Occidental with her husband Maniel.  Her husband is 64 years-old and works as a caretaker of fish ponds.  Their three adult children are busy raising their own families. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1995 and has improved her living conditionswith the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her nipa business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 20,000.

Nenita is now borrowing Php 28,000 so that she can buy and sell nipa. This will be her 14th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan, of Php 28,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Nenita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional capital

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
Ma. Fe started with a small amount of capital for her sari-sari (variety) store in 2001. Now, with all her efforts to make it bigger, she is able to provide the financial needs of her three children in sending them to school. She is 36 years old and lives in Talibon, Bohol.

Ma. Fe needs additional capital of Php 15,000 as a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to buy groceries for her store and make it more productive.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda T., 32 years old, owns a rice farm. She has five children with the eldest being 12 years old. She keeps on thinking of a good business to venture into so that she will be able to provide the basic needs of her family.

Linda is managing her farm with her husband and desires an abundant harvest. She said that she learned to farm since she was just a kid: her parents taught her everything.

Linda wants to make her farm productive in honor of her late husband. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 4,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Reinerio

texts.en:
Reinerio is a 39-year-old fisherman from Talibon, Bohol, who catches fish to provide for the needs of his family. He is married to Ma. Chuchie and has four children. He has fifteen years experience in fishing. He wants to live a healthy life and be able to send his children to school. 

Reinerio joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in 2003 and finds it helpful for his business. He is currently asking for a loan of 15,000 Php to provide more supplies for fishing.

loans.use: To provide more supplies for fishing

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta N., a rice grower from Trento Agusan Del Sur wishes to obtain a loan. She wants to increase her harvest by buying all the farm supplies she needs.

Loreta has seven children, her eldest being 19 years old. She is quite happy with the income she earns from her rice farm.

Loreta hopes to receive a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because, aside from the fact that it is providing the loan, it also enrolls all its clients in an insurance program.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura, 43, goes fishing to earn a living and her business helps a lot in sending her children to school. She has five children and her eldest is still 25 years old. She wishes them to finish their studies soon.

Laura joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to partner her business. Currently she is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP to continue to support her business. This is a big help for her in sustaining her business and her family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is the mother of ten children and she supports them by selling fish around her community. She started this business a long time ago and this is the only way she can support her family.

Anecita sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to have additional capital for her business. She asked for a loan of 5,000 Php. This will be helpful in improving her business and will not be burdensome to repay since it has a low interest rate.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna M., 52 years old, said that she benefits a lot from growing rice. Her husband is also a farmer and both of them work so hard to be able to raise income for their family.

Lorna desires to increase her harvest but needs additional capital to buy all the farming necessities. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. The loan will go far in buying fertilizer and farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina owns a sari-sari (variety) store, her only way of earning an income for her family. Her store started in 2003 and now it’s improving. She requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to help finance her business.

Gina is the mother of five children and wishes them to earn a degree. She’s asking a loan of 10,000 Php to buy more groceries for her store. This will sustain her business and family.

With her loan, Gina hopes to repay at the proper time.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn M., 41 years old, is the farmer of a small parcel of rice farm. She is also the mother of eight children and desires to prosper her business to be able to save money for the future of her family.

Currently, they are planting rice seedlings. Marilyn would like to grow her harvest so that she will be able to get larger shares of rice grain. Deep inside her, she desires to have her own farm.

Marilyn would like to ask for a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy P. is currently in the business of selling onions and bags of charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock more onions to sell. Nancy is 22 years old and is married to a businessman. She has one child and her child goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more onions to sell

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
As the mother of three children, Marilyn J., who is 41 years old, dreams of having a sustainable livelihood for her family.

Currently Marilyn has a farm where she grows and sells rice to provide her children with all their needs. The income that she makes from growing rice helps to pay for school tuition and books and also helps to pay the daily costs in their home.

Marilyn desires to add to her business capitalization. She wants to apply for a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. The loan will go far in buying fertilizer and farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Kafuki

texts.en: Kafuki P. is currently in the business of selling beer and charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more beer and charcoal to sell. Kafuki is 40 years old and is widowed. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more beer and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
When she started her business in 2008, Merlinda Furtunato’s goal was making her business grow to support her family.

Merlinda, 25 years old, tills a small rice field, which is 1-hectare (2.5-acres) in size. She wants to have an abundant harvest but lacks capital to buy all the farm supplies. She would like to request a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. The loan will really help her to go on in her farming business and to have sustainable income for her family. The loan will help buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Hopefully the income will help her save money to raise her two-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Isaiah

texts.en:
N. Isaiah is a hardworking man aged forty-four years. He is a resident of Nansana Kampala. He is a doctor by profession and he owns a clinic which he has been operating for over four years. He employs one person in his clinic.

Isaiah is using the loan to purchase medicines and so forth to meet his customers’ needs. He is a hardworking businessman whose dream is to improve his clinic.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Wasu

texts.en: Wasu S. is currently in the business of selling bread and ice cream and is requesting a loan to stock more ice cream and bread to sell. Wasu is 37 years old and is married to an electrician. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more ice cream and bread to sell

loans.name: Tunna

texts.en: Tunna M. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes to sell. Tunna is 28 years old and is married to a farmer. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Monika

texts.en: Monika J. is currently in the business of selling soft drinks in her shop and is requesting a loan to stock more boxes of juice and crates of soda to sell. Monika is 40 years old and is married to a soldier. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more boxes of juice and crates of soda to sell

loans.name: Clementina

texts.en:
Clementina P. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.

Clementina is 37 years old and is widowed. She has seven children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.


About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Santa Kumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Santa Kumari N. is a farmer in the village of Dolchoki. Dolchoki is one of the developing villages located in Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are farmers. Mrs. N. has eight members including herself in her family. She lives with her husband, Mr. Jay Krishna N., and six children. Her husband works in a government office. She has four sons and two daughters. All of her children are now studying in secondary school.

Mrs. N. grows green vegetables on her land. She mostly grows seasonal vegetables and sells in the local market in the mornings and evenings. Now she is requesting a 10,000 Nepalese rupee loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for her agricultural farming.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers for her farming

loans.name: Dil Kumari

texts.en: Mrs. Dil Kumari N. is a farmer in the village of Dolchoki. She owns a piece of land where she grows vegetables. She mostly grows green vegetables and sells in the local market in the morning and evening daily. Now she is requesting her first loan of 10,000 Nepalese rupees to buy seeds and fertilizers for her vegetable farming. She uses her income to fulfill the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers for her farming

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en: Rolando N. is a farmer. He has one child who is only 1 year old. As the head of the family, he thinks of ways to provide his family with an adequate supply of food, clothing and other basic needs. He is busy on the farm. He has been tilling it for so many years now. He would like to apply for a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies

loans.name: Tari

texts.en:
Tari M. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family including her husband and three children. Her husband, Mr. Shyam M., works in a catering service. She has one daughter and two sons. Her daughter is studying in grade 12 and her sons are studying in secondary school. 

Mrs. M. set up her grocery store two years ago to improve the economic condition of her family. Her husband and daughter also help her in the shop. She sells different types of grocery goods such as rice, maize, cold drinks and various types of snacks. She requests a loan of 30,000 Nepalese rupees to buy grocery goods. She will also use this loan to expand her shop.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en: Rosalie S., 48 years old, is a tenant on a 2 hectare rice field. She has seven children. She helps her husband manage the farm so that they will have an abundant harvest to feed their family. She dreams of having a farm someday; that is why she is doing her best to prosper and improve their harvest. She would like to apply for a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos at Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Laxmi M. is a grocery store keeper in the village of Thecho. She opened her grocery a few years ago to uplift the economic condition of her family. She sells different types of grocery items in her shop such as rice, maize, biscuits, noodles, snacks, cold drinks, etc. Now, to meet the increasing demands of her customers, she is requesting a 20,000 Nepalese rupee loan to invest in her shop. 

Mrs. Laxmi lives with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Dhana Raj M., is a carpenter. She has one son and one daughter. Both of them are now studying.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
When she started her business in 2000, Pamela L.’s goal was to make her business grow to support her family. Pamela, 33 years old, tills a small rice field which is 1-hectare (2.5-acres) in size. She has one child who is seven years old.

Pamela wants to have an abundant harvest but lacks capital to buy all the farm supplies. She would like to request a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. The loan will really help her to go on in her farming business and to have a sustainable income for her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Sita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sita M. is a tailor in the village of Bhakepati, Lalitpur. She opened her tailoring shop a few years ago to uplift the economic condition of her family. Before starting her own business she took six months training for tailoring work.

Mrs. Sita M.’s specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like kurta sulwar (a pant and tunic outfit), blouses, ladies long dresses, makhshi, and others.

Mrs. Sita M. lives with her husband and three children. She has two sons and one daughter, all of them now studying. She plans to use the loan to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to add to her family's income and support her children's education.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring work

loans.name: Anu

texts.en:
Mrs. Anu B. is a tailor in the village of Bhakepati, Kathmandu. She lives with her husband, son, and daughter. Both of her children are in pre-school. Her husband, Mr. Suresh B., went to Dubai for work.

Mrs. B. opened her tailoring shop seven years ago. Before starting her own business, she took a three-month training course from a tailor shop near her home. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies' dresses, like the Kurta Sulwar (a pant and tunic outfit) which is very popular among Nepali women.
