His wife operates a sewing business at her home.

Currently, Sanjsuren operates a transportation business with his car. He has been transporting local residents between the provinces with his car and has loyal customers because of his goO. service. In addition, he has been expanding his business and he has been planning to purchase a truck with a capacity of 3.5 tonnes for a trucking business.

He is a very hardworking person and his business is very important to him. He says, “I would like to expand my business and increase my business profit.” Sanjsuren is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~ 352 USD) loan for fuel cost and contribute money to purchase a truck for his business.

loans.use: To purchase fuel and to put towards a new truck

loans.name: Uma

texts.en:
Mrs. Uma K. is a resident of Sainbu-Bhaishepati. Sainbu-Bhaishepati is located in Lalitpur district. Sainbu-Bhaishepati is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in vegetable farming.

Mrs. Uma lives in a single family with her husband and one son. Her son is studying in pre-primary school.

Both Mr. and Mrs. K. are engaged in poultry farming. They opened their poultry farm five years ago. They buy small chickens and sell them after 50 to 60 days. They fulfill all the needs of the family with the income from this business.

Now Mrs. K. is requesting a RS 10,000 loan to buy small chickens and food grains for the chickens.

loans.use: To buy small chickens

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For grocery business

loans.name: Rima

texts.en:
Mrs. Rima B. is a resident of Sainbu-Bhashipati which is located in Lalitpur district. It is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in agriculture.

Mrs. Rima B. lives with her husband and one son. Her husband, Mr. Rajendra, is in the Nepal army and her son is studying in pre-primary school.

Mrs. B. started her goat-raising business three years ago to help her husband financially. Now she has five goats. She buys baby goats and sells them in the local market after four to five months. This business helps her to improve the economic conditions of her family.

Now, Mrs. B. is requesting an Rs 30,000 loan to buy ten more baby goats for her business. She will also use the loan to buy feed for her goats.

loans.use: To buy ten baby goats and goat feed

loans.name: Sita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sita P. is a grocery store-keeper in the town of Sanepa. She opened her grocery store two years ago to improve the economic condition of her family. She sells different types of grocery items such as rice, maize, noodles, beaten rice (dehusked rice which is flattened into flat light dry flakes), etc.

Nowadays, the demand for grocery goods is increasing, due to the migration of people from different places to Sanepa. So Mrs. Sita P. is requesting her first loan of Rs 10,000 to buy grocery items for her shop.

Mrs. Sita P. lives with her husband and four children. Her husband works in a private office and all her children are now studying.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Issan

texts.en:
Issan Shawki Ibrahim B. is 43 years old and is married. His family lives in Gaza and includes nine members with five school students.

Issan has a beverages store and aims to enlarge his business through increasing his purchases. This will increase his sales and increase his profit.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for his store

loans.name: Marouf

texts.en: From the A. Sheikh Radwan area, Marouf Manar A. K. is a 23-year-old single man operating a shop selling and fixing electronic scales. The financiA. return of this business will enable him to get married,  and he is now requesting this loan to enlarge his business and buy new materials and electronic scales.

loans.use: To purchase electronic scales

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad Hussein A. H. is 46 years old, a secondary school graduate, and a married man with seven members in his family. Two of his children  attend school in Al Nasyrat, Gaza.  Mohammad owns a grocery store for which he is requesting a loan to buy additional foodstuffs to enlarge his business and increase his profit, his ultimate goal being to raise his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for his grocey store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more beans for resale

loans.name: 11Th Street United Business Group

texts.en: For more than 10 years, Amara S. has been selling car tires retail in Monrovia, Liberia. He is 46 years old, married and has three children ranging in age from 10 to 17. He attended Arabic School through 12th grade but could not continue due to financial problems. Amara sells his tires at affordable prices and talks to customers in a nice manner which keeps customers returning. But he's had trouble finding adequate cash in order to buy more inventory. He plans to use his portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more tires to increase his stock. His goal is to send his children to school and build a house. Amara is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "11th Street United Business". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Amara is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more tires for resale

loans.name: Women In Power Group

texts.en:
For 3 years, Beatrice D. has been selling fish at the Thinker’s Village Market in Paynesville, Liberia. She is 57 years old, married and has seven children. She did not have the opportunity to go to school due to financial problems.

Beatrice sells quality fish which keeps customers returning. She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 38,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more fish to improve her business.  She dreams of building a house and sending her children to school.

Beatrice is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "Women In Power". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Beatrice is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase more fish

loans.name: God's Time Is The Best Group

texts.en:
Cecelia G. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Time Is The Best. She is 47 years old, married, and has seven children ranging in age from 5 to 24. She could not continue her education through the 8th grade due to financial problems.

For more than 5 years, Cecelia has been selling general goods at the Duazon market in Margibi County, Liberia. 
She started by being a gardener and was able to raise capital to get into the general goods business. Displaying her goods in a nice way keeps Cecelia's customers returning. However, she says she has a problem making enough money to pay for her children's school fees.

Cecelia plans to use her portion of this 40,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more goods to improve her business. Her hopes and dreams are to build a house and to sponsor her children to complete their schooling.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Cecelia is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to improve her business.

loans.name: Plumkor Community Group

texts.en:
Plumkor Community Development Project is a group of five borrowers led by Momo K., a 43-year-old married man. Momo has three children aged 8 to 13 years old with educational levels of 4th to 7th grade.

Momo is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to lack of financial support. He then decided to get into business. He lives in Plumkor Community which is a very poor and crowded community where people strive for their living. It is near Monrovia, the capital of Liberia.

Momo's business is timber. He buys timber whole sourced from rural Liberia and sells to the residents of Monrovia. He started this business through the efforts of friends. Because it was during the Liberian civil crisis that Momo started his business, he used to face difficulties from rebels that always seized his goods. But, because he kept his head up, he was always trying to succeed.

Momo maintains his customers by selling good timber. He has been running this business for nine years and is hoping to improve his business to a better standard. He needs this loan to buy more timber to improve business.

Momo plans to use his 26,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 80,400 Liberian dollar loan to buy more wood planks.  His dream is to open a storefront one day.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Momo is the one holding the sign.

  
About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.name: Partner In Progress Group

texts.en: For five years, T. L. has been selling plastics and bags at the Water Side Market in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He is 43 years old and married with three children, ages 4 to 18 years old. T. is a high school graduate but did not continue his education to college due to lack of financial support. T. started selling with 100 Liberian dollars (LRD) and now has 25,000 LRD as working capital. He says he sells goods that are in demand which keeps his customers returning. T. plans to use his 8,000 LRD portion of this 40,000 LRD group loan to purchase more plastics and bags for sale. His hopes and dreams are to improve himself to a higher level in the near future. T. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "Partner In Progress". In the photo that accompanies this profile, T. is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more plastics and bags for sale

loans.name: God Knows Us Group

texts.en: Moses J. is the leader of this group five borrowers called God Knows Us. In the photo, he is the one holding the sign. He is 57 years old, married, and has five children ranging in age from 21 to 37. He could not continue his education through 3rd grade due to financial problems. For five years, Moses has been selling foodstuffs such as rice and oil at Gbengar Town in Paynesville, Liberia. He says that when he sells, he always keeps sweets (candies) for his customers' children which keeps them returning. But he feels that he faces a problem in that, if he gets ill, his business will not go on. Moses started selling with money from his retirement savings. He plans to use his portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase a wheelbarrow in order to transport his rice to far places for sales, and to be able to buy and transport additional rice. Moses’ hopes and dreams are to build a house and improve his family's living conditions. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase a wheelbarrow for the transport of rice

loans.name: Jesus Is Lord Group

texts.en:
Mardia L. is the leader of a group five borrowers called Jesus Is Lord. She is 43 years old, married, and has five children ranging in age from 7 to 26.  She finished high school and started attending college, but had to drop out due to financial problems.

For more than 10 years, Mardia has been baking bread for sale at the 72nd community on the SKD Boulevard in Paynesville, Liberia.  She prepares her bread well and approaches her customers in a nice manner which keeps customers returning.

But she faces problem when supplying customers who do not want to pay on time.  She plans to use her portion of this 36,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase some baking materials such as flour, sugar, and butter. Her hopes and dreams are to build a house for her family if her business improves in the near future.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mardia is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase some baking materials such as flour, sugar, and butter.

loans.name: Archival

texts.en:
31-year-old Archival is a hardworking father to three children. He is married to Melania. He is involved in fishing and just started a small store that his wife manages. He says that he prays to God for his business to prosper and for strength to withstand all the challenges he faces. Like other fathers, he wants to give his children proper education.

Archival applied to CEVI and asks for a loan of PHP 9,000. He will use it to buy an engine for his boat and hopefully other fishing materials. This loan will help him catch more fish to sell.

loans.use: Engine for boat

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en: Elvira sells herbal medicines for a living. She is 45 years old and married with two children, who go to school. Elvira says that she chose to be involved in this business because she wants to help people in her community use herbal medicines for greater health benefits. She is hoping to acquire more stock for selling. She applied for a loan of PHP 8,000 from CEVI, which she will use to increase her inventory.

loans.use: herbal medicines

loans.name: Fetersonia

texts.en: Only 22 years old, Fetersonia is the mother of a two-year-old child. She is married to Abgel, who goes out to the sea to fish, and she sells everything he catches. She goes around her community to sell fish and dries some to sell as well. She applied to Community Economic Ventures, Inc to gain access to its financial services. She asks for a loan of PHP 6,000, which she will use to buy fish nets and other fishing materials. She says that receiving this loan will be truly helpful as she hopes to have more fish to sell so she could also earn more.

loans.use: Fish nets and other fishing materials

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
69-year-old Francisca manages a sari-sari (convenience) store in her house in Trinidad, Bohol. Now a widow, she is left with seven children to take care of. She says that she hopes for her store to prosper so that she would be able to provide for her family. She still sends some of her children to school. She dreams for them to finish college and have a bright future.

Francisca sought the help of an MFI to support her business. She joined CEVI and asks for a loan of PHP 10,000, which she will use to acquire supplies for her store.

loans.use: Store supplies

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa, a 48-year-old married woman, sells detergent for a living. She has two children whom she hopes to have proper education and a bright future. She is thankful that her business is currently going well and she hopes for it to grow more. She also wants to try selling other products for a broader range of customers.

Josefa is seeking a loan of Php 8,000, which she will use to increase her stock of detergents. This loan will truly help Josefa increase her working capital.

loans.use: increase her stock of detergent

loans.name: Jover's Group

texts.en: Jover T.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. He is 30 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Cabungaan, Clarin. Jover has been in his business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Jover joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Jover has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jover is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his third loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of his children. Jover is the leader of a four member group accessing a loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to broaden her inventory

loans.name: Hongorzul

texts.en:
Hongorzul is 34 years old and lives with her husband and son in Uvurhangai Province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger". They have been living together in their current home for eight years. 

Hongorzul and her husband sell motorcycle parts at a local market called Uv-Tehnik (Inheritance-Technics). They sell a variety of Chinese and Russian motorcycle parts, repair equipment, and painting supplies. They purchase their products once or twice a month in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 

Her working capital now exceeds 2,520,000 tugrugs (~ $1775 USD) and her average monthly sales revenue exceeds 800,000 tugrugs (~ $562 USD). Hongorzul's monthly profit is 215,000 tugrugs (~ $150 USD). She now operates her business in a shipping container that she owns. In the future, she plans to purchase a tire repair center, expand her production line, and increase the quantity of products that she sells. 

Hongorzul is a very enthusiastic and hard-working person. She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrugs (~ $700 USD) loan to purchase tire repair equipment for her business.

loans.use: To purchase tire repair equipment

loans.name: Mrs. Noen Chek Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Chrey Young village in Kandal province, eighteen people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Noen C. is a village bank president who has been selected by the group members who will use this loan for different purposes. She and her husband are vegetable sellers. Since their business is going well, they want to expand. Thus, Mrs. Noen C. decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. This couple has six children, two of whom are seamstresses in garment factories and the others are attending the local public school. All the members are shown in the picture but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth E. is from the city of Mabini Santiago. She is 56 years old and the leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Elizabeth E.'s group. Elizabeth is married and has three school-aged children. She has run a general store for the past two years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Elizabeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Thai

texts.en: Mrs. Thai S. A. is a domestic farmer, 23 years old, who lives with her own small family in Kompong Cham, a province of Cambodia. She owns a small farmland that she inherited from her grandmother, on which she cultivates various crops for a profit. She has a life partner in her husband, 25-year-old Brok Sok, a farmer. He climbs many palm trees to tap palm juice for his wife to boil to be sugar to sell. This couple has a child who is still young and who assists the parents when not studying. Thai S. A. will be using her loan to buy an old motor for transportation for her family. With any remaining money from the loan, she will buy more materials for her husband to tap palm juice. Thai S. A. and her husband are hopeful that this loan will allow them to accrue more income in order to make sure their family attains a good standard of living.

loans.use: To buy an old motor and material to tap palm juice.

loans.name: Phat's Group

texts.en: This group loan has three members who live in Chrey Young village in Kandal province. Mrs. Phat C. is the group leader who has been selected by the members who will use the loan for different purposes. She is a chicken seller and a pig breeder also. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. Thus, Mrs. Phat C. decided to ask for a loan to buy more chickens to sell. She is a widow who lives in a five-member household.

loans.use: To buy more chickens to sell.

loans.name: Hera Ganga

texts.en:
Hera Ganga K. is a resident of Balkhu, Kathmandu. She lives with her father-in-law, mother-in-law, and husband. Her husband, Mr. Bikash K., owns a butcher shop.

Mrs. K. is a grocery shopkeeper in the town of Balkhu. She opened her grocery store three years ago to improve the living standard of her family. She sells different types of grocery items in her store. Her father-in-law and mother-in-law help her in her work.

Now, Mrs. K. is asking for a loan to invest in her shop to meet the increasing demand of her customers.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen E. lives in the town of Hda. Imang, Brgy San Pablo Cadiz Negros Occidental.  She is married and has 3 adult -aged children. To making a living, Helen owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari sari store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Helen has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 1994, Helen joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 29,500 Php from NWTF. Helen is now requesting a new loan of 29,500 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be the 13th loan taken out by the borrower from NWTF. Helen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calls of not just of a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Mrs. Asha M. lives in Sanepa, Lalitpur, Nepal. Sanepa is one of the busiest bazaars of Lalitpur and most of the residents in this region are engaged in small business.

Mrs. M. has four children, two daughters and two sons. All of her children are now studying. Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop four years ago. She sells different types of grocery items such as rice, maize, pulses (legumes), biscuits and noodles in her shop. Her children also help her in her work. The demand for grocery goods is increasing in her area, so she is requesting a loan of NPR 20,000 to buy grocery items to meet the demand.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Nirmala

texts.en:
Mrs. Nirmala T. lives in Sanepa, Lalitpur, Nepal. Sanepa is one of the busiest bazaars of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in small business. Mrs. T. has three daughters. Her older daughter is studying in grade 12 and the two younger daughters are studying in grade 10 and 8.

Mrs. T. opened a grocery shop two years ago. She sells different types of grocery items such as rice, maize, pulses (legumes), biscuits and noodles in her shop. Her daughters also help her in her work. The demand for grocery goods is increasing in her area, so she is requesting a loan of NPR 10,000 to buy grocery items to meet the demand.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene B. is a 25-year-old woman and a single mother of one child. She lives in Kapsaos in Eldoret and she has a tailoring business in the same area. She buys clothing material, makes clothes out of them and sells them. Sometimes her clients come with their own clothing materials. Most of her customers are her neighbors, but she also sells clothing material in different towns from market to market.

Irene was introduced to KADET by one of her friends who is also a KADET client. Her goal is to own a store where she can do her sewing work. This will be her first loan from KADET and she adds that with this loan she will be able to buy more clothing material and another sewing machine.

loans.use: To buy more material for making clothes.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 63 years old, married to Gicheha Muhuha and has five children.  She has practiced farming in Njabini town for the last 20 years.

She is among the first members to join KADET and this is her seventh year with the organization.  She has successfully applied for six loans, which she paid well and on time.  This will be her seventh loan and she plans to use the money to buy fertilizer for her farm and a dairy cow to diversify her income stream.

Since Njabini is in rural Kenya, majority of the people rely on farming as a source of income.  She, therefore, hopes to use technology in the future to increase her yield and become a reliable supplier of farm products.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and a cow

loans.name: Dhan's Group

texts.en:
Dhan R. is from the village of Brgy, Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 30 years old and the leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Dhan is married and has two school-aged children. He operates a business providing transportaion services. He has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Dhan joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. He is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair his vehicle for better service. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Dhan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair his vehicle for better service

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Mrs. B. Betty is a married woman with two young children both in primary school. She is 31 years old and owns a poultry business that she been has running for over two years. She is using the loan to purchase poultry feed, drugs, and more chicks for her business expansion. She is a hardworking woman with a good reputation. Her dream is to expand her poultry business.

loans.use: To purchase poultry feeds, drugs, and more chicks

loans.name: Erlinda's Group

texts.en:
Erlinda D. is from the village of Banquero. She is 29 years old and the leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Erlinda D.'s Group. Erlinda is married and has one school-aged child. She has run a general store for the past two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. 

In 2006, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product line. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ceferina's Group

texts.en:
Ceferina G., from the village of Del C., Cabatuan,Isabela, is the 54-year-old leader of a 14-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Ceferina, who is married and has six adult-aged children, owns and operates a specialized retail store selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 20 years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Ceferina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, her fifth, to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy correction seeds and mineral fertilizer to make his crops fertile.

loans.name: Buke

texts.en:
Buke is 32 years old, married to Galmo Ali, and they have two school-going children.  He has operated his retail shop in Olkalou for the last five years selling things like bedding (mattresses), clay pottery ovens, blankets, buckets and others.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to add more retail stock to sell, such as more mattresses, basins and buckets for household use which are in demand.

He plans to upgrade his retail shop to a mini-supermarket in the near future and also ensure sustainability of his family with basic needed items.

loans.use: To buy mattresses, basins and buckets to sell

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina C. is from the village of Santiago, Iligan City. She is 39 years old. Rosalina is widowed and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalina sells scrap metal and other used products in the local community. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Flordeliz

texts.en:
Flordeliz A. started her own backyard piggery and poultry raising operation in order to help with the growing financial needs that raising her four-year-old child has brought. Through the proceeds of these businesses Flordeliz hopes to be able to have enough money to build a house and to send her child to college one day. If she's able to do that, then Flordeliz would then be able to say that her family's life is better than ever before. 

Flordeliz is requesting a loan from Kiva field partner ASHI to buy more piglets and chicks to raise. Her unemployed yet loving and supportive husband would partner her in her business. The two of them work hand in hand to raise and sell their livestock at the market and to the people in their village.

loans.use: To buy piglets and chicks to raise.

loans.name: Phildelis

texts.en:
Phildelis is 28 years old, married to Solomon Chege, and they have one child who is in nursery school.  She has been selling clothes in Naivasha town for the last twelve months.  To boost income, she also recently started selling picture frames.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to buy more clothes to sell with the money. She wants to expand her shop so that she can sell clothes for all kinds of people; that is, have children's clothing, men's clothing and women's clothing. She currently sells only women's clothing.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Josphat

texts.en:
Josphat is 58 years old, married to Margaret Wambui, and they have seven children who are all adults and married.  He has been making and selling jiko stoves (metal or ceramic charcoal stoves) in Naivasha town for the last eighteen years.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to buy more iron and metal to make more jiko stoves to sell.  

He plans to employ more people to increase production so as to cater for the ever-increasing demand for his products.

loans.use: To buy iron and metal for making more jiko stoves to sell

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is 33 years old, married to Veronica Nyambura, and they have two school-going children.  He has operated his taxi in Naivasha town for the last three years, ferrying people and goods from one place to another.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan.  His first loan of 30,000 KES was used to service his taxi and he paid the loan well and on time.  He plans to use the money he gets from this current loan to buy a new engine for his taxi.

He hopes to grow in the business industry and buy his own minibus.

loans.use: Buy a new engine for his taxi

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth is 27 years old, married to Maria Wanjiku, and they have two school-going children.  He has been a farmer for the last six years.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan to buy pesticides for his farm.

In the future he plans to increase his yield and start supplying straight to the market, avoiding using middle men who eat into his share of the profits.

loans.use: To buy pesticides

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 38 years old, married to Teresia Njeri, and they have three school-going children.  He has been a farmer for the last ten years.

Peter was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to buy pesticides for his field with this loan.

He hopes to buy a bigger farm which will increase his farm production, making him able to supply in bulk to others at the market.

loans.use: To buy pesticides

loans.name: Jovy

texts.en:
Jovy C. is from the village of Adelfa Suarez, Iligan City. She is 42 years old. Jovy is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jovy buys and sells scrap in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $100 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jovy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jovy is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Suarez, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Mrs. Magdalena G. does farming for a living. She is 63 years old and married with eight children. Her older children are already married. She continues farming to help provide for her family. She wants her grandchildren also to benefit from her business. Aside from farming, she also sells fruits and vegetables. She hopes for her business to grow.

Magdalena is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP. She will use it to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies she needs.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
48-year-old Jocelyn is a married woman from South Cotabato. She has six children, the oldest age 20. She raises ducks for a living. She also runs a small store located at her house. She says that she works hard for her children. She wants to provide them with a proper education so they will have a brighter future. 

Jocelyn joined CEVI in 2008 and says that her previous loans were truly helpful to her business and family. She is now requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP, which she will use to buy more ducks and feed. She is hopeful that this loan will help her business a lot.

loans.use: To buy ducks and feed

loans.name: Christinah

texts.en:
Christinah is 36 years old, married to Charles Githinji, and they have one child in nursery school.  She has been baking and selling cakes in Naivasha town for the last two years and she has been making good profits out of this.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the cash to buy wheat flour and cooking oil in bulk. This will make it possible for her to capitalize in making more cakes to sell.

Her future dream is to move to a more permanent place and increase her production.  She also hopes to supply her products to big supermarkets around the town.

loans.use: To buy wheat flour and cooking oil in bulk.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy, 53 years old, has seven children. Her oldest child is now 35 years old and does not live with them any more. Mercy farms for a living. She plants corn and vegetables. She works hard to help provide for the increasing needs in her household. In need of additional capital, she applied to CEVI for a loan of 8,000 PHP. She said that she would use it to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies she needs.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Meriam E. is from the village of P-Adelfa, Suarez, Iligan City. She is 40 years old. Meriam is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Meriam, together with her husband, provides upholstery services to local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over twelve years and earns approximately $145 a month from this activity.

In 2009, Meriam joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Meriam is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide her upholstery service. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide her upholstery service

location.town: P-Adelfa, Suarez, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en: Meriam owns and tills a hectare of rice farm. She is 32 years old, married with four children. Her oldest child is only aged twelve. She wants all her children to someday finish college and have a bright future. Aside from farming, she also makes charcoals and sells them around her community. Like other entrepreneurs, she wants to prosper in what she does. She applied to CEVI to gain financial support for her business. She is asking to loan Php15, 000, which she will use to acquire farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. She also hopes to increase her capital for her charcoals.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane C. is a 28-year-old woman and is married to Luke K Meli, who is a farmer. They have three lovely children. She lives in Kapsaos in Eldoret where Jane grows vegetables to sell, such as cabbages and kale.  Most of her customers are her neighbors and the market women to whom she sells her vegetables wholesale. She has been in this business for seven years now. She not only sells vegetables but also does a little dairy farming as a secondary business.

Jane came to know about KADET through a friend of hers who is also a KADET client. She has applied for a loan which she will use to buy farm supplies like different vegetable seeds for planting.

Her dream is to own a shop in Eldoret town where she can sell her vegetables and also to expand her farming business.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like vegetable seeds.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz J. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 49 years old. Luz is separated from her spouse and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Luz buys and sells vegetables in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately $135 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Luz is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
Ailyn S. is a 32 year-old woman living in the town of Brgy. 9, Isabela, Negros Occidental.  She is married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, Ailyn owns and operates a business, selling a variety of food products in the local community.  Ailyn has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately $200 a month from these activities.

In 2006, Ailyn joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ailyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from NWTF. Ailyn is now requesting a new loan of 19,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  This will be her 8th loan from NWTF.  Ailyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the school fees of her children.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon."

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell

loans.name: Caroline Cheruto

texts.en:
Caroline Cheruto L. is twenty-eight years old and a single mother to one beautiful girl. She lives in Sergoit in Eldoret and she is a farmer who plants maize and passion fruits to sell. She has been in the farming business for four years now and most of her customers are her neighbors as well as one of Kenya’s biggest maize suppliers, the National Cereals Produce Board. She also has a secondary business which is a retail shop where she sells fast-moving foods. 

She came to know about KADET through another KADET client who is her neighbor. This will be her first loan from KADET. With the entire loan, Caroline is going to buy farm supplies like maize seedlings and passion fruit seedlings. 

Her future dream is to be able to get more income so that she can buy some land of her own where she can expand her farming business.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like maize seedlings.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda H. is from the village of Kiwalan, Iligan City. She is 47 years old. Rosalinda is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda sells clothing and shoes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately $88 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rosalinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Kiwalan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: James Wanyoike

texts.en:
James is 40 years old and he is in the business of transporting people and goods from one place to another using his motorcycle. He is married to Charity who is a businesswoman and they have one son and two daughters. 

James was introduced to Kadet by another client. He plans to purchase another motorcycle with the loan. With the extra profits expected from the business, he intends to buy a Three Wheeler Taxi (Tuk Tuk) for his transport business. 

In the near future he hopes to buy a Nissan Matatu for his transport business. James describes himself as a person who loves people and is very jovial.

loans.use: To purchase another motorcycle

loans.name: David Muiruri

texts.en:
David is a gentleman who is 31 years old. He is in the transport business where he uses a motorcycle to ferry people and goods from one place to another. He has been in this business for the past two years. He is married to Mary who is a farmer and they have one son aged 10 years and one daughter aged 6 years.

David was introduced to KADET by another existing KADET client. With the loan he has applied for, he plans to purchase another motorcycle for transport. He intends to invest back in KADET and buy a three-wheeler taxi (Tuk Tuk) with the extra profit generated from his business.

David’s future hopes are to own a fleet of transport vehicles and also employ more people. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman, very jovial and happy to serve his customers.

loans.use: To purchase another motorcycle

She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Junila decided to request a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children’s education. location.town: Kiwalan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Josinta

texts.en:
Josinta R. is the twenty-eight-year-old mother of two children who is married to Joasiah Imbali, a painter. Their two children, James and Lin, are in a local primary school.

Josinta runs a stall, selling groceries, cereals and clothing in Manyatta estate, a low income settlement estate in Kisumu City. Her stall is located near a pathway and thus is easily accessible to many, especially women who come to buy fruit and vegetables for their families. Josinta has been running this business for the last ten years.

A friend introduced Josinta to KADET and she is currently taking her second loan, after successfully repaying a first loan without difficulties. She plans to purchase more cereals for sale and use part of the money to venture into a wholesale stocking of household items (locally known as mali mali). 

Josinta’s hope is to one day open a permanent and spacious stall for clothes, separate from cereals and vegetables. Josinta, a self-motivated woman, wants to educate her children and later buy a plot of land and build a residential home.

loans.use: To buy more cereals to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase maize, beans and rice in bulk

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen O. O. describes himself as a hardworking man from Kisumu City, which is along the shores of Lake Victoria, Kenya. He is married to Hellen Awuor, a housewife and they have three children: Robert, aged 8 years who is in grade two of primary school; Thomas, aged 6 years and in grade one of primary; and 4-year-old Elizabeth, who is in baby class.

Stephen runs a spare-parts business whereby he sells motorcycle and bicycle spares. His business is located in Manyatta, a populous residential estate in Kisumu City. His main customers are the motorcycle and bicycle passenger transport businessmen (locally known as boda boda). He taps the majority of them because his shop is located on the busy main road which leads to the estate and also there is a nearby market center.

Stephen joined KADET after friends introduced him and he is taking his fourth loan. He intends to use the loan to buy more motorcycle spare parts since they are in high demand. His wish is to find a lender, through KADET to enable him to further his business. He is optimistic that he will make profits from which he will open a business for his wife because he believes that this will increase the family income, hence improving their standard of living.

Stephen’s hope is to transform his business to wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more motorcycle spare parts for his business

loans.name: Luz

texts.en: 68-year-old Luz M. uses her skill in dressmaking for a business. This is her way to earn money and help her children financially. Despite her age, Luz still dreams of having her own dress shop in the future. She wants her clothing designs to be recognized by more people, not just in her own village but in the whole town as well. She is requesting another loan from ASHI. Her family, especially her grand children, are her reasons to work hard and grow her business. She wants them to experience a better kind of life through the profits from her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for dress making.

loans.name: Aurea's Group

texts.en:
Aurea R. is from the village of Tawagan, Labangan ZDS. She is 45 years old. Aurea is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Aurea is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Aurea raises ducks for sale. Aurea has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately $150 a month from this activity.

Aurea joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurea is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase ducklings to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 1st loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 37-year-old Elizabeth P. K. from Mbarali. She is married with six children between the ages of 12 and 20 years. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans.

Elizabeth has been running a cloth selling business since 2009. Her business is purchasing clothes wholesale and selling them retail. She works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by her husband. 
Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 600,000 Tsh in order to purchase more clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of her clothes. Elizabeth thanks you for your support!


About SELFINA: 
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Lydie Baï

texts.fr: A. Lydie Baï est née le 26 Mars 1966 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Lydie Baï vit depuis 36 ans au quartier Sainte Rita à Cotonou. Mariée à GBEDEY Mesmin, Lydie Baï a cinq enfants à sa charge, tous scolarisés. Lydie Baï vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure les différentes charges familiales. Lydie Baï a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Lydie Baï prépare et vend de la nourriture (riz, pâte de maïs et de cossette d'igname) au marché de Sainte Rita. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Lydie Baï s'approvisionne. Lydie Baï sollicite pour une première fois, de crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Lydie Baï A. was born on 26th March 1966 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. She has lived for the past 36 years in the Sainte Rita district of Cotonou. Lydie Baï is married to Mesmin GBEDEY and has five children in her care, all of whom are at school. She lives with her children and husband. The couple share responsibility for the various family expenses. Lydie Baï left school during secondary level. In order to cover her needs, she prepares and sells food (rice, corn dough and "cossette" made from dried yam, at the market in Sainte Rita. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. Lydie Baï is applying for a loan from ALIDé for the first time in order to build up her stock of products and to strengthen her activity.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, corn and yam "cossettes"

loans.name: Salwa

texts.en:
Salwa S. is a 39-year-old married woman from Gaza. She is living with her husband and five children who have all entered school.

Salwa has been working in a grocery store with her husband since 2009. She is hoping that, through this loan, she will be able to buy new refrigerators for the store in order to keep all their dairy products fresh. This will bring in new customers and will increase their income.

loans.use: To buy new refrigerators for the store to keep their dairy products fresh

texts.en: Emma R. is from the village of Barina-ut, Iligan City. She is 43 years old, is married, and has one adult child. Emma owns and operates a business providing transport services in the local community. Her husband has been the driver of their small jeepney (small bus) for over eight years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for jeepney maintenance as well as to buy other needed materials to provide better service. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Emma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. Elly is a hardworking man who is married with four children who go to school. He runs a shop where he offers battery charging services. He has been in this business for seven years and has one employee. He also rears chickens to earn more money to provide for his family.

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, Elly’s business has grown because he is able to access loans. He hopes to grow his business and improve his standard of living in the future. He has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 to buy battery acid and battery chargers.

loans.use: To buy battery chargers and battery acid

loans.name: Hélène

texts.fr: Née en 1961 à Toffo Agué dans le département de l'Ouémé au Bénin, A. Hélène vit depuis vingt ans au quartier Dogoudo à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique. Hélène est mariée à YAKPLEDO Paul, et est mère de sept enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais seulement trois des enfants vivent encore avec son mari et elle, à Dogoudo. Le couple se partage ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Hélène n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins, Hélène a commencé à produire elle-même, de la farine de manioc qu'elle vend au marché de Allada. Il y a juste un an que Hélène a commencé cette activité. Hélène achète ses matières premières à Allada. Hélène est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a bien remboursé les trois premiers prêts qu'elle a reçu de ALIDé. Hélène sollicite un autre prêt afin d'agrandir un peu plus son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1961 in Toffo Agué in the"département" (administrative district) of Ouémé in Bénin, Hélène A. has lived for the past twenty years in the Dogoudo district of Allada, in the "département" of Atlantique. Hélène is married to Paul YAKPLEDO and is mother to seven children, all of whom have been or are at school. However, only three of the children still live with her and her husband in Dogoudo. The couple shares responsibility for the various family expenses. Hélène never went to school. In order to provide for her needs, Hélène has started to make cassava flour herself, and she sells it at the market in Allada. She began this activity just a year ago. She buys her basic products in Allada. Hélène is an old customer of ALIDé, who has repaid all three previous loans that she was granted by ALIDé. She is applying for another loan in order to expand her activity a little more and to satisfy better her customers.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cassava

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en: Tabitha, 46 years old and married with seven children, has been farming since 2008. She sells milk to earn income and also practices other forms of farming. Since she joined Faulu, her living standards have really improved because she can access loans. She hopes to grow her business and improve her living standards and is now requesting a loan of kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a dairy cow. Tabitha describes herself as hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ma. Pinky

texts.en:
Ma. Pinky G. is a simple woman with simple ambitions in life. She is a housewife, in charge of her family's needs inside the house and budgeting the family revenues for food and other basic needs. She is worried that she and her husband will not be able to support the needs of their five children whose age range is from three to twelve years old.  Pinky’s perception is probably true because her husband is the only one who has an income. It is very small and sporadic because he is just a hired carpenter. This family issue pushed Ma. Pinky to request for a loan through ASHI which will be used to purchase a motorcycle for a transportation business to be managed by her husband. Income through this business is much bigger than being a carpenter and is regular.

Someday, Ma. Pinky hopes to support her children’s education to a higher level and for them to have better lives in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Foluke

texts.en: Foluke sells peppers and tomatoes in Lagos state, Nigeria, where she resides, and she also grinds them for additional income. She started this trade some years ago and has done well, using her income to support her household.  Fifty-years-old and married to a transporter, Foluke is the mother of four children, three girls and one boy.  She is now requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more fresh tomatoes and peppers to sell to her costumers to increase her profit. She is very happy with Kiva lenders for the financial assistance they offer.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh tomatoes and peppers to sell.

loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
Nelita P., from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province, is 38 years old, married, and the mother of two school-aged children. To make a living, Nelita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over eight years, she earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

Nelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to invest in expanding the business, she is now requesting a new loan, her second, of 8000 PHP to invest in further expanding the business. Nelita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane, a 41-year-old widow with two children who go to school, has been running a salon with two employees for six years to earn a living. She also sells vegetables to Nairobi residents.  Treating her customers well and meeting their demands keeps them returning.  Jane, who has been saving her money with Faulu Kenya, which in turn has helped her to manage her finances, is now requesting a loan of kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy towels, a blow  dryer and chairs.

loans.use: To buy towels, a blow dryer and chairs for the salon

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Zamindii

texts.en: Zamindii is 53 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. They have been living together in their current home for 30 years. Currently, he operates a carpentry business with his wife in his town. In his business, he manufactures wooden products and his wife, Oyunchimeg, paints them as well as makes other small works for their business. They started their business with working capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~ 140 USD). After years of successful operations, he has managed to increase his working capital to a level exceeding 2,000,000 tugrugs (~ 1407 USD) today. Zamindii is a very hard-working person who has good communication skills. He is focused on the future and says, “I would like to expand my business and to purchase new equipment for my business.” He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~ 705 USD) loan to purchase necessary materials including timber and paints for his carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Adedoyin

texts.en: Adedoyin is a 40-year-old married mother of five children, all attending school, and this gives her joy. Her husband also works to meet the basic needs of their family. Adedoyin lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria, where she sells crates of drinks at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction with her customers. Adedoyin is now requesting a loan amount of 50,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Molunrayo

texts.en: Molunrayo is a 25-year-old mother of three children between three and nine years old. Married to an iron-bender, she owns a beauty salon and also sells hair extensions and cream to her customers. Molunrayo, who has been in the business for over 12 years and is very happy with its growth, currently employs two apprentices in her shop for more effective customer service delivery. She hopes for the loan of NGN 50,000 to buy more hair cream and hair extensions to sell and thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To buy more hair cream and hair extensions to sell.

loans.name: Paz

texts.en:
Paz A., from the village of Upper Luinab, Iligan City, is a 48-year-old widowed mother of eight adult-aged children. To make a living, Paz owns and operates a business selling firewood in the local community. Engaged in her business for over a year, she earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Paz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, she is now requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. Paz plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Upper Luinad, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Dorica

texts.en:
Dorica, a 42-year-old widow with three children who are in school, has been running a salon with three employees for four and one-half years to earn a living. She has many return customers because of her customer care skills. Dorica also sells second-hand clothes to earn enough money to provide for her family and pay school fees for her children.

Previously a poultry seller, Dorica has really developed her current enterprises since she joined Faulu Kenya because of her access to loans, and she hopes to further grow her salon and open another type of business in the future. Dorica is now requesting a loan of kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a foot spa, hair dryer and hair weaves.

loans.use: To buy a foot spa, hair dryer and hair weaves

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Altantulga

texts.en:
Altantulga is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. They have been living together in their home for 16 years. Currently, Altantulga operates a second-hand product business with his wife in his town. He sells a variety of used products including clothing and blankets to his many customers. 

He started his business in 2004 with 400,000 tugrugs (~ 282 USD). After years of successful operations he has managed to increase his working capital to a level exceeding 1,200,000 tugrugs (~ 845 USD) today. With his business profit, he has been providing money toward his family expenses and his family's quality of life has been improving. 

Altantulga is a very hard-working person and has many plans for the future. He says, “I would like to expand my business and to create my own workplace in the future.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~ 1407 USD) loan to purchase large amount of second-hand products at wholesale prices for his business.

loans.use: To purchase second-hand products for resale

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud M. is a 21 years old, single man from Gaza. He is living with his parents and 5 siblings. Since 2007, he has been working in a meat store. Now, he is hoping that through this loan he will be able to buy meat and frozen fish for his store, which will bring in more customers and increase his income.

loans.use: buy meat and frozen fish to sell

loans.name: Zacheous

texts.en:
Zacheous is 35 years and he lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. He is married with two children who both attend school. His wife also works to support their home.
Zacheous is a farmer and also a pastor. He has a very large farm where he plants cassava. He has been in this business for 17 years. He hopes to expand his farming business, and is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more cassava stem to plant. He sends thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava stem to plant

loans.name: Yédéba

texts.en:
Yédéba S. is 37 years old. She is married to a policeman and has two children. She lives with her family in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo. Mrs. S. sells beans, honey, and women’s shoes. She purchases her stock from the Grand Marché in Lomé, and then sells her products in Agoé. 

She began this business in 2007 and is now requesting her first loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to purchase 2 sacks of beans, 1 barrel of honey, and use the remainder to purchase women’s footwear. This loan will contribute to the continued growth of Mrs. S.’s business and the well-being of her family.

loans.use: Purchase of beans, honey, and women's shoes for resale

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is 29 years old, single with two children who go to school. She runs a boutique where she sells clothes to earn a living. Her business is located in Embakasi, a few kilometers away from the capital city, Nairobi. She has employed one person.
