She hopes to grow her business and offer her children a better education in the future.    She has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy men’s shirts, dress tops, and dresses.

loans.use: To purchase men's shirts, dress tops and dresses

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en: Jacob is 61 years old and married with eight children. He is a carpenter who makes lovely furniture to sell. He has been in this business for a long time, and loves it because it is highly profitable. Jacob is a hardworking man who hopes to lift his business and family above poverty. He is very punctual in his business because he believes that punctuality is the soul of business. He is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more wood in order to make more furniture to sell. He sends his thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for furniture-making

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is a 26-year-old, determined lady. She sells clothes to earn a living. She has employed one person. She also sells chips to earn extra income.  She appreciates Faulu Kenya for training her in the importance of business record keeping.  She hopes to expand her business and improve her living standards in the future.  She has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy more clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy clothes for sale

loans.name: Anhbayar

texts.en: Anhbayr is 29 years-old and lives with her husband in Zavhan province, Mongolia. She and her husband live together in an apartment which they own. Her husband operates a transportation business and transports his customers between the provinces. During the day, Anhbayr operates a consumer goods trading business in her town. She sells a variety of goods as well as clothing to her many customers. Anhbayr has been operating her business since 2008 and has steadily expanded her business. Before starting her own independent business, she worked with her parents who operated a consumer goods trading business. Anhbayar has gained much experience in previous years as a businesswoman. She says, “I am working hard to create my own workplace in the future.”  She is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug (~ 18000 USD) loan to purchase more inventory for spring and autumn from Ereen, a Chinese border town.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Flikissilou

texts.en: Flikissilou I. is 35 years-old and married with two children. Mr. I. lives and works in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo. He sells fabric and cloth used to make clothing. Mr. I. purchases his supply from the Grand Marché in Lomé and then sells his products in a smaller, local market. He began this business in 1999 and is now asking for his first loan from Kiva partner WAGES. He will use this loan to add more stock to his inventory by purchasing 100 new sheets of quality fabric. It is hoped that that this loan will help Mr. I.’s business to flourish.

loans.use: To purchase fabric.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita A. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years-old and married with seven school-aged children. To make a living, Rita owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products in the local community. Rita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rita joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. Rita is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Rita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Veronicah

texts.en: Veronicah is 28 years-old and married with one child who goes to school.  She has been running a green grocery for four years.  She also keeps poultry for commercial purposes to assist her husband with the household expenses. Her husband is a businessman and they are able to afford a decent lifestyle. She was previously employed in a hardware shop before she started this business. Since she joined Kiva partner Faulu Kenya, she has acquired business management skills from the training they offered her. She is requesting a loan of kes 20, 000 from Faulu Kenya to add stock of potatoes, carrots and onions.

loans.use: To add stock of potatoes, carrots and onions.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel, a 62-year-old resident of Oyo State, Nigeria, is the married father of six children and is very happy in his business of raising pigs to sell and operating a poultry farm. Hoping to make his businesses more sustainable, Emmanuel is requesting a loan of 50,000 to purchase more pig feed. He says ‘THANK YOU’ to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more pig feed

loans.name: Baasanhuu

texts.en:
Baasanhuu is 50 years-old and lives with her husband and son in Zavhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a “ger” in a yard which belongs to her brother. They have been living together in their current home for two years. Currently, Baasanhuu operates a door-to-door meal trading business in her town. She makes the meals at her home and delivers them to her customers.

Baasanhuu started her business in 2009 and has steadily expanded her business and gained experience. Originally, she had a small restaurant at a local vocational trading center between 2005-2009. Her business is well known amongst her customers and she has been planning to create her own workplace in the future. Baasanhuu is a very hardworking person who has good communication skills. She says, “I am working hard to be financially supportive for my son's life.”  She is requesting a 300,000 tugrug (~ 225 USD) loan to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat.

loans.name: Younis

texts.en: Younis S. is a 32-year-old married man from Gaza. In 2009, Younis opened his own electric store and now is in need of new electrical equipment. He is hoping that through this loan, he will be able to buy all the supplies he lacks. Doing so will bring in more customers, which will increase his income.

loans.use: buy all the supplies he lacks

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is 35 years old and married with three children who go to school. He has been running a green grocery for seven years.  His wife usually assists him with the household expenses since she is employed.  Elijah also rears chicken and sells eggs locally to his neighbors and friends to get more money.  

He was previously employed by a horticultural firm before he started this business.  He hopes to expand his business since he can access loans from Faulu Kenya. He has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more fruit, carrots, potatoes, and onions for sale.

loans.use: To add stock of fruit, carrots, potatoes and onions

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gbenga

texts.en: Gbenga, a resident of Oyo State, Nigeria, sells spare motor parts at retail prices to his customers. In this business for a long time, he now needs a loan of N50,000 to purchase more spare parts to sell. Gbenga, 42, is a hardworking married father of three children, all in school, a fact that gives him joy. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more spare motor parts to sell

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma C. is from the village of Tag-ibo, Dalipuga, Iligan City. She is 47 years old. Emma is married and has 7 children. To make a living, Emma owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products as well as "hypo"or all-purpose detergent powder in the local community. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Emma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Emma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Tag-ibo, Dalipuga, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en:
Batjargal is 33 years old and lives with his wife and son in Zavhan province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent, in a rental yard. His wife, Nasanjargal, looks after their 1-year-old son at their home. 

During the day, Batjargal operates a transportation service in his town. He transports local residents to and from various points in the area. He has had success with his business and has built a reputation as a good driver. 

Batjargal has been operating his business since 2006, together with his younger brother, and has been planning to purchase another micro-bus to transport more customers in his province. Batjargal gained much experience over the past years and has many plans in the future. He has been planning to purchase own house with a yard for his family with his business profit in the future. 

Batjargal is a enthusiastic person and says, “I am working hard to build a successful life and improve my family's quality of life.” He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a micro-bus for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a micro-bus for his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing additional commodities in bulk

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en:
42-year-old Adenike sells cooked food and drinks at her restaurant in Lagos. She has been in the business for the past twenty years and she is well known in her community because she knows how to cook good food and at a very cheap rate.

Adenike is married with three children and her husband is a businessman involved in clearing and forwarding.

Adenike is happy with the nature of her business but needs to boost it. She is asking for the loan of NGN 160,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell to her customers. This will increase her profits and sustain her family’s financial needs.

Adenike appreciates all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Battumur

texts.en:
Battumur is 44 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Zavhan province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife, Uranchimeg, is a nurse in a local hospital. They have been living together in their current home for twenty years.

Presently, Battumur operates a transportation and timber-trading business in his town. During the winter, he transports coal and for the other three seasons he transports timber to Gobi-Altai province. He has been operating a transportation business for thirteen years, as well as a timber trading business for five years, and has steadily expanded his businesses.

Battumur has gained much experience in previous years and has a loyal customer base. He is a very hardworking person with a good personality. He says, “I am working hard to create financial security for my children's future.”

Battumur is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase more timber for his timber-trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more timber to sell

loans.name: Jamil

texts.en:
Jamil A. is a 52-year-old married man from Jenin. He lives with his wife and four children, two of whom have entered school.

Jamil has been working in a grocery store since 2006. He hopes that, through this loan, he will be able to pay his debts, buy groceries for his store, and improve the economic status of his family.

loans.use: To pay debts and purchase goods for his store

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en: Marivic A. is from Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Marivic owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies like peanuts and more in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the needs of relatives and other family members. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Tolu

texts.en:
Tolu is 61 years old, married, and has four children. She sells drinks, sachet water and groceries to make a living. She is very happy with the growth of her business. With her previous Kiva loan through Kiva partner, LAPO, she was able to stock her shop with more groceries and drinks. This increased her profit margin and provided financial assistance for her family.
Even at her age, Tolu is still enthusiastic about the growth of her business and family. She wants her business to get better and better. Her hope is to make her shop a drinks depot where customers can buy drinks in large quantities so that she can make more profit. Tolu is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more drinks, sachet water and groceries to sell. She expresses her huge gratitude to all lenders who choose her as their borrower.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, sachet water and groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her mama lishe

loans.name: Purevjav

texts.en:
Purevjav is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in a rental yard.

During the day, Purevjav operates a carpentry business in his town. He designs and produces a variety of wooden products to sell to his many customers. He started his business in 2000, and has expanded his business and increased his working capital as well. He is well-equipped and has gained much experience in previous years.

Purevjav is a very hardworking person with a good personality. He would like to expand his business by investing more money in his business and increasing his business profit in the future. He is requesting a 700,000 tugrug loan to purchase more wood for his carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for his carpentry business

loans.name: Olayemi

texts.en:
Olayemi is 35 years old, married, and has three children. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. Olayemi sells groceries, such as milk, sugar and toothpaste, and has been in this business for 12 years. In the future, she hopes to own a supermarket. Olayemi is a hardworking woman who is determined to pull her business and family out of poverty. She is a client of Kiva partner, LAPO, and is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

About LAPO
Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Florencia M.’s greatest dream is to free herself from the spiral of poverty. In 1999, she decided to join Kiva partner, ASHI (which means “To Rise Up from Poverty”), in the Philippines. Since she joined ASHI, she has shown a good performance in her credit rating (the basis of loans) and is therefore able to borrow a larger amount of capital for her businesses.
As a busy entrepreneur, Florencia is engaged in multiple businesses – hog-fattening, retailing, frozen foods and sewing. These businesses allow her to save money as she and her husband get older. They want to enjoy their future retirement and be able to live with a happy family.
Florencia is now on her eleventh loan, and she has applied for the amount of 23,000 PHP to maintain her frozen food business, to buy additional piglets and feed, and support the inventory of her sewing business.
In the future, Florencia hopes to establish a stall in the nearby town market where she can take orders from her customers. Her dreams are to provide a better future for her family and sustain the profitability of her businesses. Through hard work and determination, Florencia is focused on improving her quality of life through her entrepreneurial initiatives and with support from ASHI and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To maintain her frozen foods business, to buy additional piglets and feed, and support the inventory of her sewing business

loans.name: Geneviève Aline

texts.fr: H. Geneviève Aline est née le 09 Septembre 1978 et est mariée à ASSOGBA Séïbou, un soudeur. Le couple a trois enfants à charge, dont deux sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Geneviève Aline vit depuis neuf ans à Cocotomey, dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, avec sa famille. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Geneviève Aline a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Depuis six ans environs, Geneviève Aline mène comme activité, la vente de diverses articles de mercerie dans sa boutique située à son domicile. Geneviève Aline s'approvisionne au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin, et à Dantokpa, marché international du  Bénin. Geneviève Aline avait bénéficié d'un crédit auprès de ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement. Dans le but d'élever davantage le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Geneviève Aline sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Geneviève Aline H. was born on 9th September 1978 and is married to Séïbou ASSOGBA, a welder. The couple has three children in their care, two of whom are their own children. All the children are at school. Geneviève Aline has lived for the past nine years with her family in Cocotomey in the municipality of Calavi. The couple shares the various family expenses. Geneviève Aline left school during secondary level. For around six years she has sold various haberdashery products in her shop which is based at home. She gets her supplies in Nigeria, which borders Bénin, and in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. Geneviève Aline has already benefited from one loan from ALIDé which she repaid in full. With a view to expanding her activity and to be able to satisfy ever increasing customer demand more readily, she is applying for a second loan.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 50 rolls of poplin, 70 packets of sewing thread, 30 dozen zippers, etc.

loans.name: Maritchel

texts.en: Maritchel A. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin province. She is 28 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Maritchel owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Maritchel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Maritchel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Maheshwori

texts.en:
Mrs. Maheshwori M. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. Thecho is one of the under-developed areas of Lalitpur. She lives in an extended family with her father-in-law, mother-in-law, husband and one daughter. Her husband, Mr. Rajendra M., is engaged in making brass religious statues.

Mrs. M. opened her tailoring shop eight years ago after six months of training in tailoring from a local tailoring shop. She makes different types of custom-fitted ladies’ dresses in her shop. She prefers to make women's clothes such as kurta-salwar (a pant and tunic outfit), blouses, petticoats, long dresses and dresses for newborn babies.

Mrs. M. is now asking for a loan of Rs 30,000 to buy raw materials like cloth and thread, and a cutting machine for her tailoring work.

loans.use: To buy raw materials and a cutting machine for her tailoring work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice and maize flour as additional ingredients for her mama lishe

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en: Thelma F. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin province. She is 50 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Thelma owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Thelma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Thelma is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Alma Fe

texts.en:
Alma is a 29-year-old entrepreneur from Tagbilaran City, Bohol. She is married with three children, her oldest child being only aged ten. She dreams of her children someday finishing college and having a bright future.

Alma makes local delicacies for a living. She makes camote (cooked sweet potato) and ube bars (snacks made with purple yam), squash fries and many other items. Her major buyer is Bohol Bee Farm, a resort and restaurant that promotes organically grown products. She dreams of starting her own factory so that she could also help unemployed people in her community.

Alma is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 which she will use to buy raw materials and ingredients for making delicacies. This loan will help Alma reach her dreams in life.

loans.use: To buy raw materials and ingredients for making delicacies

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
33-year-old Alma raises hogs to earn a living. She is married and has three children, her oldest child being only nine years old. Alma works hard to be able to keep up with the increasing needs in her household, especially her children’s education. She said that it’s one of the major challenges she and her husband currently face because school fees keep increasing.

Alma is seeking a loan of Php 8,000, which she will use to acquire additional piglets and feeds. This loan will truly help Alma sustain her business.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Javzandulam

texts.en:
Javzandulam is 41 years old and lives with her siblings in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Javzandulam operates a dairy trading business in her town. She sells a variety of dairy products such as curd, yogurt, and milk to her many customers. She has been operating her business since 1999, and has steadily expanded her business as well as gained valuable experience.

Javzandulam has been planning to expand her business in the future. Besides her dairy trading business, she worked as a director of Begze-AR partnership between 2005 and 2008. Then she worked as a general manager for Tsagaan Dalai Fund in 2008.

Javzandulam has a great business mind and managerial skills. She says, “I would like to expand my dairy trading business.” She is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more dairy products and raw materials for her dairy trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products and raw materials

loans.name: Aniouvi Justine

texts.fr: Née le 03 Décembre 1965 à Avrankou dans le département de l'Ouémé, H. Aniouvi Justine vit depuis 19 ans à Lobozounkpa dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Aniouvi Justine est mariée à ADJIGUIDI Antoine, un plombier, et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Aniouvi Justine vit avec ses enfants et son mari et le couple assure les différentes charges familiales. Aniouvi Justine n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Depuis huit ans, Aniouvi Justine mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (biscuits, sucre, lait, détergents, etc.) aux marchés de Cococodji et de Cocotomey. Aniouvi Justine s'approvisionne sur le marché international de Cotonou, et aussi au Nigéra, Etat voisin du Bénin. Aniouvi Justine a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. En vue d'accroître davantage son activité et de pouvoir gagner une grande part de marché, Aniouvi Justine sollicite un second prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born 3 December 1965 in Avrankou in the Ouémé Department, Aniouvi Justine H. has been living for the past 19 years in Lobozounkpa in the Abomey Calavi commune. She is married to Antoine ADJIGUIDI, a plumber, and is the mother of three children, all having attended (or still attending) school. She lives with her children and her husband, with whom she shares the handling of family expenses. Aniouvi Justine has not attended school herself. For the past eight years, she has been selling various products (cookies, sugar, milk, detergents, etc.) at the Cococodji and Cocotomey markets. She gets her supplies from the international market in Cotonou, and also from Nigeria, a country adjacent to Benin. Aniouvi Justine has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was fully repaid. To expand her business and acquire a larger market share, she is now requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 20 cartons of cookie packages, 15 cartons of boxed milk, 16 cartons of sugar packages

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional wheat flour, beans and other ingredients for her business

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en: Eugenia L. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin province. She is 53 years old, is separated from her spouse, and has two school-aged children. Eugenia owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over forty years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Eugenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Eugenia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
K. Nulu is twenty-seven years old and owns a retail shop. She has been in a business for three years. She is using the loan to expand her business by purchasing retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, and so forth, especially necessities.

Nulu has five children who are schooling. Her future plan is to own a wholesale shop so as to increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase items such as sugar, salt, soap, and so forth

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
N. Harriet is a resident of Yesu Amala, Nansana. She is a married woman blessed with two children.

Harriet owns a salon business and, at the same time, carries out tailoring services. She is using the loan to purchase beauty salon items and cloth for making different designs for her customers.

Harriet is encouraging and her dream is to improve on her salon and to have enough stock of clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase beauty salon items and material for making different designs for her customers

loans.name: Badmaarag

texts.en:
Badmaarag is 24 years old and lives with her two children, parents and siblings in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her parents produce shoes and sell them to their customers, and they help a lot with their daughter's business as well.

Currently, Badmaarag operates a tailoring business in her town. She started her business in 2004, and has started to rent a counter with her family at a local trading center called a Ar-Hatan-Trade. Her business is supported by the entire family and they have built a stable operation.

Over the years, Badmaarag has steadily expanded her business and gained much experience as a businesswoman. Today, her monthly revenue exceeds 600,000 - 800,000 tugrugs (approximately 440 - 575 USD). She and her family equally share all the profits that they gain from their businesses.

Badmaarag is a very open-minded person who has many plans for the future. She says, “I would like to grow my business to a stable operation, and to keep contributing to my family’s finances.” She is requesting a 240,000 tugrug loan to purchase more fabric and materials for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
N. Catherine is thirty-five years old and has a clothing business situated at Kalerwe. She has been operating her business for over four years.

Catherine is using the loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Purposely the loan is increasing her working capital as well as improving her stock.

Catherine is an encouraging business woman whose dream is to own a big clothing shop.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita A. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin province. She is 46 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Rosita owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rosita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional fruit for her business

loans.name: Ritah

texts.en:
B. Ritah B. has owned and operated a retail shop for over three years. She plans to use this loan to purchase retail shop items such as sugar, salt, soap, flour, and rice for sale. She is a hard-working businesswoman whose dream is to expand her shop business. 

B. Ritah B. is married and is a permanent resident of Nkoowe. Her parents live in Kikiri.

loans.use: To purchase retail shop items such as sugar, salt, soap, flour, and rice for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional commodities for her business.

loans.name: John Bosco

texts.en: S. John Bosco is a resident of Kazifa zone, Kasangati. He is married with three children, two of whom are in school. John has a bakery at his home where he produces breads, donuts and cakes, which he supplies to neighboring trading centers. He will use his loan to purchase baking ingredients (wheat flour, cooking oil, baking powder, and so forth) in bulk so that he can make more cakes, bread and donuts to meet his customers' orders. His aim is to boost and expand his business and provide quality products to his customers.

loans.use: To purchase baking ingredients (wheat flour, cooking oil, baking powder, etc.) in bulk

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia C. is a 63-year-old woman living in the town of Hacienda Inang, Barangay San Pablo, Manapla, Negros Occidental. She is married and has seven adult children. Cecilia owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting fish from pens she constructed along the shoreline and selling fish in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over forty years and earns approximately PHP 15,000 a month.

In 2004, Cecilia joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 28,000 from NWTF.

Cecilia is now requesting a new loan of PHP 28,000 which will be used to purchase additional fish fry to raise in her fish pens. This loan will be her 13th from NWTF. Cecilia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

 About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to raise and sell

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen B. is a 51-year old married woman who lives in Brgy Sicaba Manapla Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store.

Aileen’s husband helps her in running the business and he also works to support their family. They have three adult children who are between 19 and 31 years old, two of whom help in the family business and one who is currently going to school.

Aileen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in the general store business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 20,000 from her business activities.

Aileen is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 12,000 was used to fund operations of her general store business, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now, she is borrowing for her fifth cycle loan, the amount of Php 15,000, which she intends to use on her general store. Aileen is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Maricon

texts.en:
Maricon believes that, with the support of ASHI partnership with KIVA, she can reach her goal to leave behind the cycle of poverty, develop her business, and pay for the needs of her children in school. 

As a mother with big dreams, in 2007, she decided to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), a Microfinance Institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since receiving loans from ASHI, she opened a general store and it really helped them to meet their family’s needs. 

Now on her fourth loan, she proposes the amount of 20,000 PHP to pay for sacks of rice, cases of soft drinks, vegetables, fruit, fish, and other groceries for her store.

Maricon is trying very hard to achieve a winning business to build more longterm financial security for herself and her family. One of her greatest dreams is to have a house and parcel of land to live in.

Maricon P. is a 30-year-old woman with the good faith to attempt to move away from poverty. She is a mother of four minor children, all of whom still need her support. She is married to Monico, a food vendor, who works closely with her to pursue their dreams of a secure quality life.

loans.use: To pay for sacks of rice, cases of soft drinks, vegetables, fruit, fish, and other groceries for her store

loans.name: Genedina

texts.en:
Genedina E. is from the village of  Mahinog in Camiguin Province. She is 57 years old. Genedina is widowed and has one school-aged child. 

Genedina owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for this business comes primarily from selling personal products such as glasses, watches, cosmetics, and personal products like lotion and fragrance to members of the local community. Genedina has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month from these activities. In addition to her store, she sells ‘amakan’ (woven bamboo strips that are used to dry rice under the heat of the sun).

In 2009, Genedina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Genedina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Genedina is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Genedina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her specialized retail business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk

loans.name: Nuulu

texts.en:
B. Nuulu is a resident of the Gayaza zone of Baale. She is a businesswoman with five children, three of whom are in school. She operates a retail business where she sells such items as rice, soap, sugar, chicken feed, and animal feed. She has been in her business for over five years. 

B. Nuulu plans to use her loan to purchase more of these items for sale. She wants to boost her business by purchasing products in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase products in bulk for retail sale

loans.name: Good Way Group

texts.en:
Eugenia W. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Good Way'. She is 48 years old, married, and has three children ranging in age from 22 to 27.  She could not continue her education through high school due to financial problems.

For more than 17 years, Eugenia has been selling used clothes at Gurley Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia.  She displays her goods in an organized way which keeps customers returning. But she faces problems with buying used clothes by the bale because some of the clothes in the bale can be spoiled.

She plans to use her portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to purchase more used clothes to be added to her inventory. And her hope and dream is to get into ordering used clothes by herself.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Eugenia is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to be added to her inventory

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia’s biggest dream is to have a successful pig farm someday. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. The financial opportunity of hog fattening is one of the best ways to help provide for her family and she very much wants to lift her family out of financial difficulties.  Over the years she has provided for her family by involving herself in hog raising including slaughtering and tends to a poultry business in her village.

This loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos is for hog fattening, a common business for people in her area affliction from poverty. Alicia will buy two piglets, sacks of feed, and supplements and vitamins for the piglets. She will raise them for approximately four to six months until they are ready for sale.

With the support of ASHI and its partner, Kiva  she is hopeful that her hog fattening business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy two piglets, sacks of feed, and supplements and vitamins for the piglets.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy stocks for inventory in bulk

loans.name: Ulziisaihan

texts.en:
Ulziisaihan, age 39, lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in a small house which they built themselves with profits from their business. Her husband, Ganzorig, operates a taxi service business. 

During the day, Olziisaihan has been operating a fruit and fish trading business at a Narantuul, the biggest market in Mongolia. She sells a variety of fruit, fish, beverages, and candy at her counter. 

Olziisaihan has been operating her business since 1998. At the beginning, she sold only fruit. Over the years, she gained experience, and she has expanded her product line. She has good communication skills and is focused on the future. Ulziisaihan tells us, “I am working hard to provide my children with a good education, which will be important for their future lives.” 

She is requesting a 600,000 tugrug loan to purchase more fruit and fish for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit and fish for sale

loans.name: Honorine

texts.fr: Née en 1961 à Abomey Calavi au Bénin, H. Honorine vit depuis 17 ans environs à Cocotomey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Mariée à ADANHOUNDE Joachim, Honorine est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Honorine vit avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la famille. Honorine n'a pas été à l'école. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Honorine vend des tissus de façon ambulante, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Honorine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo. Honorine a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué les remboursements. Honorine envisage augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre à la forte demande de sa clientèle. C'est donc pour renforcer son capital que Honorine sollicite un deuxième prêt de ALIDé. Honorine ambitionne plus tard ouvrir une boutique pour la commercialisation de ses tissus.
texts.en:
Born in 1961 in Abomey Calavi in Benin, Honorine H. lived her past 17 years in Cocotomey, in the Abomey Calavi commune. Married to Joachim ADANHOUNDE, she is the mother of three children, all having attended (or still attending) school. She lives with her children and her husband. The couple jointly shares family expenses. Honorine has not attended school; for the past ten years she has been an itinerant vendor selling pieces of fabric, which allows her to meet her needs and those of her children. She buys her products in Dantokpa, Benin’s international market, and also in Lomé, Togo. Honorine has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. She is considering the increase of her stock supply in response to strong customer demand. She is therefore requesting a second laon from ALIDé to reinforce her working capital. Honorine’s ambition for the future is to open a shop where she can display and sell her fabrics.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 13 pieces of fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy charcoal for resale

loans.name: Marvic

texts.en:
Marvic M., age 31, is from the village of Mambajao in Camiguin province. Marvic is widowed and has a school-aged child. To make a living, he owns and operates a business venture in the services sector, providing photographic and T-shirt printing services to local community members. Marvic has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Marvic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. He hoped to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Marvic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide his services. 

Marvic is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marvic from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to continue to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his photographic and T-shirt printing business

loans.name: Ajrahgui

texts.en:
Ajrahgui is 35 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Tosontsengel province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. They have been living together in their current home for 10 years. 
During the day, Ajrahgui operates a carpentry business with his brother. He manufactures wooden furniture such as beds, wooden trunks and beams for a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. He has been operating his business since 2005, and has expanded his business and has a loyal customer base because of his well designed products and good service. His monthly revenue is 300,000 – 600,000 tugrugs (~ 211 – 422 USD), and monthly profit is 150,000 – 250,000 tugrugs (~  105 – 175 USD). With his business profit, he provides money for his family's expenses. 
Ajrahgui is a very hard working person. The most important thing to him is being able to provide education for his children. He says, “I am working hard to be financially available for my daughters' education in the future.” He is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~  352 USD) loan to purchase a variety of wood and other raw materials for his carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase wood and raw materials.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina is a resident of Mahabang Parang, Binangonan, Rizal. She is 38 years old and married. She is seen as strong and determined to improve their standard of living. She is a caring mother of eight children, all of whom need her moral and financial support.

Currently, Christina and her husband are busy with a poultry raising business just to earn the means of living every day. When she received a small amount of capital from ASHI, she managed to put it all into her business. For her, business is an important factor, and she does not want to be a problem for her group mates or for the center in terms of paying back of loans weekly.

She applied for a new loan amounting PHP 14,000 to have additional working capital for her poultry-raising business. Specifically, the loan fund will be used to pay for chicks, vitamins, feed for the chicks, and other materials for poultry-raising. Christina performs well in her business; when she has enough capital, she expands her business in order to gain more income. 

Along with the business success she is dreaming about, is the hope to see the graduation of their children from college and to see them find a good job. She is also dreaming of constructing a home made of concrete for comfortable living.

loans.use: The loan fund will be use of paying for chicks, vitamins, feed for chicks, etc.

loans.name: Nandintsetseg

texts.en:
Nandintsetseg is 25 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ‘ger,’ the Mongolian nomadic tent dwelling, in a yard that belongs to her parents. 

Presently, she operates a tailoring and clothing trading business in her town. She manufactures a variety of clothing and leather bags using customer-specified designs. Nandintsetseg has been operating her business since 2007, after she graduated from the Urlah Erdem Institute of Fashion and Design. In addition to her tailoring business, she operates a clothes trading business at a rented counter. 

Over the years, she has expanded her business and has gained valuable experience. She has been planning to build own house for her family (with her family's help), and already she has started the building process using the profits from her business.

Nandintsetseg is a friendly person who has many plans in the future. She tells us, “My dream is to have my own salon for my tailoring business. In addition, I would like to expand my business into a more stable operation.” 

She is requesting a 600,000 tugrug loan to purchase more clothing for her clothes trading business.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing for her clothes trading business

loans.name: Victoire Houndema

texts.fr: G. Victoire Houndema est née le 29 Décembre 1960 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à MAHOULIKPONTO Edmond, un maçon, Victoire est mère de huit enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Il y a 21 ans environs que Victoire s'est installée au quartier Akadjamey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, où elle vit avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différentes charges de la famille. Victoire n'est jamais allée à l'école. Depuis 15 ans, Victoire mène comme activité la vente de feuilles et plantes de la médécine traditionnelle dans une barraque à Gbodjè (Cotonou). Victoire s'approvisionne à Adja, Sè et à Glazoué au Bénin. Victoire a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Dans le but d'augmenter son stock de produits et de mieux répondre aux besoins de sa clientèle, Victoire sollicite un deuxième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Victoire Houndema G. was born 29 December 1960 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Married to Edmond MAHOULIKPONTO, a mason, she is the mother of eight children of whom some have had schooling. She settled 21 years ago in the Akadjamey borough of the Abomey Calavi commune, where she lives with her children and her husband. She shares with him the various family expenses. Victoire has never attended school; for the past 15 years, she has sold traditional medicinal leaves and plants in a stall located in Gbodjè (Cotonou). She gets her supplies from Adja, Sè and Glazoué in Bénin. Victoire has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. Wishing to increase her stock of supplies in response to customer needs, she is now requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 5 dozen canaris (earthenware), 7 bags of tree bark, 6 bags of tree roots, 8 bags of leaves.

loans.name: Riverlee Sisters Group

texts.en:
Decontee M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Riverlee Sisters'. She is 49 years old, married, and has five children ranging in age from 7 to 32.  She could not continue her education past 7th grade due to financial problems.

For 20 years, Decontee has been selling soft drinks at the Riverlee Cinema on Broad Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She approaches her customers in a nice manner which keeps customers returning. But she has a problem with carrying soft drinks to the Ministry of Finance right opposite where she also sells because she has to climb stairs to get to customers.

Decontee started by selling peanuts. She plans to use her portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to purchase more soft drinks to improve her business.  And her hopes and dreams are to send her children to school and build a house for her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Decontee is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more soft drinks to improve her business

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita B. is a 54-year-old mother of six grown children, all of whom are degree holders. She hails from the town of Binangonan, Rizal Province, in the Philippines. She is married to 58-year-old Tagumpay, her partner in business and a supportive husband.

Pacita joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2006. Since then, she has had access to capital for her business. She used her previous loans for direct-selling of Avon products and jewelry products and it has been great for her family. The business is running smoothly and bringing in enough proceeds.

Now on her fourth loan, Pacita is applying for 15,000 pesos as additional working capital to have more stock to sell in her business. She hopes that through the loans she has obtained from ASHI in partnership with Kiva, someday she will be able to discover her talent to engage in a more productive business.

Pacita dreams of continuing her business as a sustainable livelihood to support her family, so as to provide them with a better life that is far away from under the umbrella of poverty.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her business

loans.name: Naranhuu

texts.en:
Naranhuu is 37 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house which they own. Her husband, Baatarsuren, is a government employee with a monthly salary of 300,000 tugrugs (~ 211 USD). Currently, Naranhuu operates a clothing trading business at a Narantuul, one of the biggest market in Mongolia. She sells a variety of clothing, especially women's clothing. She has been operating her business since 2005, and has built her business to a consistent level and attributes its success to her strong selling and communication skills. Today, her working capital exceeds 3,500,000 tugrugs (~ 2112 USD), and her daily revenue is 50,000 – 100,000 tugrugs (~ 35 – 70 USD). 
With her business profit, she purchased a car and built a house for her family. She is a very hard working person and Naranhuu has been planning to open her own clothing shop in the future. She says, “I would like to be financially available for my three children's education.” She is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~ 2465 USD) loan to purchase more women's clothing, from China, for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Shirheerev

texts.en:
Shirheerev is 36 years old and lives with her wife and three children in Zavhan province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. They have been living together in their current home for three years. 
Shirheerev operates a carpentry business in his town. He produces a variety of wooden furniture including beds, beams, and doors for a ger, the traditional Mongolian tent. He has been operating his business since 2007, and has steadily expanded his business. His monthly sales revenue is 300,000 – 500,000 tugrugs (~210  –  350 USD), and his monthly profit is 100,000 – 200,000 tugrugs (~ 70 – 140 USD ). Shirheerev is a very hard working person. He is requesting a 300,000 tugrug (~  211 USD) loan to purchase a variety of wood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase wood for carpentry.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy beans, rice as additional ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Erdenechimeg

texts.en:
Erdenechimeg, age 54, lives with her husband in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her husband live together in a ‘ger,’ the Mongolian nomadic tent dwelling, where they have lived for 15 years. 

Presently, Erdenechimeg operates a wood products manufacturing business with her husband. They have operated their business since 2000, and over the years they have expanded its scope and become experienced manufacturers. In addition to this business, Erdenechimeg has been renting out a pool for a profit since 2005. With the business profits they have gained over the years, they have been able to afford their children’s education fees and to support them in purchasing homes and living on their own. 

For the future, Erdenechimeg and her husband are focused on growing both of their businesses. Erdenechimeg is a very hardworking person and says, “My husband and I are working hard to improve our quality of life.” 

She is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan to purchase more wood for their wood products manufacturing business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for their wood products manufacturing business

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: N. Sarah is a business woman and a resident of the Kasubi Area. She has a shop along Kasubi-Kawada Road where she sells clothes. She is married and has three children, all in schooling. She is thirty-eight years old. She is using the loan to purchase stock of clothes in order to meet and exceed her customer's demands, so she is trying her level best to improve on her business by expanding it. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to expand the business.

loans.use: To purchase stock of clothes in order to meet her customer demands.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional bags of tomatoes and onions for her business.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan U. joined ASHI because she wanted to have her own business, since her husband's income as a construction worker is not sufficient to sustain the daily needs of their family. She will use her second loan of Php 10,000 in her retail and food-vending business.

Susan and her husband aim to use ASHI loans to develop a stable business so they can save for the education of their two children and have their own home someday. She is optimistic and strong enough to face the challenge of poverty.

With the opportunity given to their family by ASHI and Kiva, the couple believes that it is getting nearer to the achievement of their family dreams.

Susan is 29 years old. She joined ASHI in 2009. She is married, and has two minor sons, Wilson and Nelson.

loans.use: To be used in her food-vending business

loans.name: Bayarsaihan

texts.en: Bayarsaihan is 43 years old and lives with his wife and two young sons in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Presently, he operates a meat trading business and a taxi service in his town. He started his meat trading business  in 2004 with a working capital of 300,000 tugrugs (~ 212 USD). In this business, his wife, Ariuntungalag, sells the meat at a local market. They have steadily expanded their business and today, following a lot of hard work, their working capital exceeds 1,000,000 tugrugs (~ 705 USD). In addition to the meat business, he started operating a taxi service business in 2007. This business was started with a car which Bayarsaihan purchased with his meat business profits. He uses his business profit to provide money for the family's expenses. Bayarsaihan is requesting a 1,300,000 tugrug (~ 915 USD) loan to purchase a variety of meats in order to resell them for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Théodora

texts.fr: Née en 1970 à Abomey dans le département du Zou, S. Théodora vit depuis quinze ans à Gbodjè, dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi au Bénin. Théodora est mariée à ANANI Noel, un menuisier, et est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Théodora vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure les différentes charges de la famille. Théodora a très peu fréquenté, mais a appris la couture. Théodora exerce cette activité depuis huit ans environs. Parallèlement à cette activité, Théodora vend des articles de mercerie et aussi des bijoux dans son atelier situé à son domicile. Théodora s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Théodora  avait une fois bénéficié de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Dans l'optique de renforcer son activité et d'accroître son chiffre d'affaire, Théodora sollicite un deuxième prêt de ALIDé. Théodora ambitionne plus tard construire un nouveau lieu de vente de ses produits.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Abomey in the "département" (administrative district) of Zou, Théodora S. has lived for the past 15 years in Gbodjè in the municipality of Abomey Calavi in Bénin. She is married to Noel ANANI, a carpenter, and is mother to three children who are all at school. Théodora lives with her children and husband. The couple share responsibility for the various family expenses. Théodora went to school very little but learned how to sew. She has been carrying out this activity for around eight years. In parallel, she sells haberdashery products and also jewelry in her workshop, which is in her home. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. Théodora has had one loan from ALIDé which she repaid in full. With a view to strengthening her activity and increasing her turnover, she is applying for a second loan from ALIDé. Her ambition is to build another sales point for her products later on.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 18 rolls of poplin, 10 dozen zippers, buttons, etc.

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr: Née en 1971 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, G. Véronique est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Véronique est une veuve qui s’est installée à Cocotomey dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi, depuis six ans environs. Véronique vit seule avec ses enfants et assure leurs différentes charges. Véronique n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Véronique prépare et vend de la nourriture (pâte de maïs, igname pilé, accompagnés de différentes sauce) dans sa boutique à Cocotomey. Véronique s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Véronique exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans, et a déjà obtenu un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Véronique sollicite un deuxième prêt en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1971 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, Véronique G. is mother to two children who are both at school. She is a widow who settled around six years ago in Cocotomey in the municipality of Abomey Calavi. Véronique lives alone with her children and takes responsibility for their various expenses. She did not go to school. In order to provide for her needs, she sells food (corn dough and crushed yam, accompanied by various sauces) in her shop in Cocotomey. Véronique gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. She has been carrying out this activity for five years and has already had one loan from ALIDé, which she repaid in full. Faced with growing customer demand, Véronique is applying for a second loan in order to reinforce her business and satisfy her customers more readily.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of five bags of corn, two bags of yam, three cartons of fish and meat, condiments.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice and beans for her cafe business

loans.name: Germaine

texts.fr: Née en 1981 à Cocotomey dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi, où elle y vit depuis sa naissance,  H. Germaine est mariée à HOUESSINOU  Willis, un photographe. Le couple a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble et le couple assure les différentes charges du foyer. Germaine n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Après son abandon de l’école, Germaine a appris la coiffure et exerce cette activité depuis huit ans. Parallèlement, Germaine vend des mèches et des produits cosmétiques dans son atelier situé à Cocotomey. Germaine a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. Germaine désire agrandir davantage son activité et mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle. C’est donc pour renforcer son activité que Germaine sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Germaine H. was born in 1981 in the city of Abomey Calavi (Cocotomey, Benin), where she has been living since. She is married to Willis Houessinou, a photographer. They have three schooled children, and the couple takes care of all household expenses together. Germaine had only attended primary school. After stopping her studies she learned hairstyling, and has been working as a hairdresser for the past eight years. In parallel, Germaine is selling cosmetic products and hair extensions from her store in Cocotomey. Germaine has already received two loans from ALIDE, and has reimbursed them promptly. Germaine would like to increase the scope of her activities even more to be able to better meet the needs of her customers, which is why she is now requesting her third loan from ALIDE.

Translated from French by Dina Dumenko, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetic products and hair exensions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional cloth for her business

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel is 36 years old, is married, and lives in the province of Rizal in the Philippines with her husband and three young children.

To supply additional income for her family, Maricel is opening a local convenience store as her primary business and operates a secondary business of sewing in her neighborhood. She has been an entrepreneur for almost nine years.

Maricel would like to receive a loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase inventory including rice, sugar, shampoo, detergent, canned goods, and other items for her store. She believes in offering a relevant assortment of goods in her store for customers seeking convenient purchases.

Maricel joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, in 2006 to obtain secured access to capital and loans to fund her entrepreneurial dreams.

Maricel’s longterm goals are to expand her general store business, fund the education of her three children, have their own house and lot, and support her family financially. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she is determined to achieve business success with her entrepreneurial endeavors.

Maricel hopes that these dreams will come true and that ASHI will, in fact, give the best direction and opportunity to her family.

loans.use: To purchase inventory including rice, sugar, shampoo, detergent, canned goods, and other items

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: N. Sarah is a resident of Mpererwe Kiyonya Zone and has a retail shop in Mpererwe trading center. She has been in business for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase retail shop items such as soap, sugar, rice, flour, sweets, bread, biscuits, salt, and so forth to meet her customers’ demands. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to expand the business.

loans.use: To purchase retail shop items

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: D. Christine est née le 24 Juillet 1970 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à CODJO Anani, un soudeur, Christine est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Christine  vit depuis 11 ans au quartier Gbodjè, dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, avec sa famille. Le couple se partage ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Christine n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Christine mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (détergents, pâtes alimentaires, conserves de tomate et de sardines, sucre) et des articles de merceries à Gbodjè. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Christine achète ses produits. Christine a bénéficié une fois déjà de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué le remboursement. Christine sollicite un deuxième prêt, afin d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de se faire plus de revenus.
texts.en:
Christine D. was born July 24, 1970 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Married to Anani Codjo, a welder, Christine is the mother of three children who are all educated. For 11 years, Christine has lived in the Gbodjè quarter, in the Abomey Calavi community, with her family. Together, the couple shares different family responsibilities. Christine never went to elementary school. Ten years ago, Christine began selling various products (detergent, dough, tomato and sardine preserves, sugar) and dry goods in Gbodjè. She buys her products in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Christine has already received one loan from ALIDé which she repaid in full. She is asking for a second loan in order to increase her stock of products and see more profits.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 8 rolls of preserve boxes, dough, and detergent

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
In 2006, Erlinda joined ASHI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in entrepreneurial business activities. She and her husband, Roque, have successfully repaid a previous loan from ASHI.

Erlinda owns and operates a dressmaking business in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a week. With additional working capital, Erlinda’s business will continue to expand and she will be able to offer satisfactory service to her customers.

Erlinda therefore hopes to expand her business; she is requesting a loan of 25,000 pesos to pay for different cotton fabrics and other supplies for her business. This loan will be her eighth loan from ASHI. Erlinda requests this loan so that she can support the expansion of her dressmaking business and be able to meet the growing demands of her customers.

Having this opportunity of obtaining loans from Kiva through ASHI will provide a chance for Erlinda to accomplish her goals in life: to have a growing business, a good living, the financial means of supporting her family and funding for the college education of her two children.

Through the support of ASHI, in partnership with Kiva, Erlinda hopes to see herself and her family soon change their standard of living and get away from living beneath the umbrella of poverty.

loans.use: To buy different cotton fabrics and other supplies

loans.name: Bakary

texts.fr:
Monsieur Bakary Sidibé est un homme marié de 31 ans et père de 2 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier Dougounina de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire pour des raisons sociales, il commença très tôt les activités économiques, notamment manuelles à savoir la mécanique, la tôlerie, l'électricité auto, la soudure etc auprès d’un garagiste très apprécié de la place. Finalement Bakary mettra l’accent sur la tôlerie au détriment des autres. Avec une expérience de 10 ans, il maîtrise son activité et est très sollicité.
C’est dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires qu’il décide de rejoindre le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Il est à son premier prêt et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, une quantité de pièces détachées entrant dans les activités de tôleries (mastique, colles, gaz pour chalumeaux, baguettes, etc). 
Bakary s'approvisionne à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et exerce toujours au garage où il a fait son apprentissage, avec une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Bakary espère réaliser un bénéfice de 35.000 FCFA par mois qui lui permettra d’agrandir son entreprise et subvenir aux dépenses de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Bakary Sidibé is a 31-year-old man, married, and father of two children. He lives with his wife and children in the Dougounina quarter in the town of Bougouni (third administrative region of Mali). Never having attended school for social reasons, he began working very early, notably training in mechanics, sheet-metal working, automobile electricity, and welding at a local and respected garage. Eventually, Bakary chose to work with sheet metal over the other options. With ten years of experience, he is often solicited for his business. When researching supplementary financial options, Bakary decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microcredit program. He is on his first loan and counts on using it to buy a large quantity of various materials used in sheet metal work (gum, glue, gas for torching, rods, etc.). Bakary gets his supplies in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and always works in the garage where he learned the business. His clients are diverse and varied. Bakary hopes to make a monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA which will allow him to grow his business and contribute to his family's needs.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various materials
