loans.name: Korotoumou

texts.fr:
Madame Korotoumou D. est une femme mariée de 25 ans et mère de 2 enfants qui vit avec ses enfants chez son époux dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région du Mali). 
Korotoumou a abandonné l’école dès son jeune âge, pour se livrer aux activités génératrices de revenus en  choisissant finalement le secteur de l’habillement. Avec ses années d’expériences, elle maîtrise son activité d’achat et la vente de pagnes dans laquelle elle s’est perfectionné  auprès de sa mère.
 Dans le souci  d’obtenir un fonds de roulement, Madame Korotoumou D. décida de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso.  
Après  3 prêt solidaire dans un groupe, elle est à son premier prêt individuel.Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt elle compte acheter, des pagnes wax et brodés, à Bamako (capitale de république du Mali) auprès des grossistes. Elle mène cette activité dans les différents quartiers de la ville et  au marché tous les jours des foires. 
Elle compte réaliser  avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 55.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Korotomou D. is a 25-year old woman, married and the mother of two children. She lives with her husband and children in the North Hérémakono area of the Bougouni (in the third administrative region of Mali).Korotomou has dropped out of school at an early age in order to be able to work and earn an income, and finally she has settled on a clothing business. Thanks to her long experience, she is now very skilled in buying and reselling “pagnes” (traditional fabrics for wrap clothing), a trade she has learned from her mother. In order to increase her business capital, Mrs. D. has decided to join Soro Yiriwaso. She had obtained three previous joint loans as a member of a group. This would be her first individual loan. All previous loans have been properly reimbursed. With this loan, she is hoping to purchase a supply of wax and embroidered “pagnes” from wholesale traders in Bamako, the capital of Mali. She sells her wares in different districts of town as well at the marketplace on market days. With this loan, she is hoping to achieve a monthly income of 55,000 West African francs, which will serve to enlarge her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing "pagnes" (traditional fabrics)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional charcoal and chicks

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac M. is thirty-four years old, is married, and has three children. He engages in boda-boda (a motorcycle fitted with a tailor-made seat over the rear wheel) transport. He runs this business in the Kimbo area at Thika. Thika is in the central Kenya and is known for the large-scale production of pineapples.

Isaac has been in this business for the last two years. He says that the major challenge in this kind of business is the high cost of maintenance of the motorbikes. He says that the business is good, regardless of the challenges, and that is why he is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy another motorbike.

Isaac plans that in the future he will buy more motorbikes which will improve his income in a big way. He is a very hardworking man.

loans.use: To buy another motorbike

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice, wheat flour, and maize flour

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew N. M. is fifty-six years old. He is married and his wife takes care of the daily household chores.

Mathew's business is located at Landless Estate, a residential area in Thika, and it is well-known by the name “Blessed One”. He owns a general store which sells such items as detergents, soft drinks, loaves of bread, and even vegetables. He serves the residents of Landless Estate and the local construction workers.

Mathew has been in this business for the last three years and he says that, although this business is good, there are so many people in the area doing the same kind of business as his and so his customers are spoilt for choice. However he works very hard from early morning to late evening to ensure that his business is doing well.

Mathew is using his loan of 50,000 KES to restock his general store and hopes that his business will grow into a wholesale business some day. He also hopes to educate all his children to university level. He is a very hardworking and honest man.

loans.use: To buy detergent, soft drinks, etc., to restock his store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice, beans and maize flour

loans.name: United People Group

texts.en: Marie W. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called “United People”. She is 48 years old, is married, and has a 30-year-old child. Her responsibilities also includes a sibling. Marie did not have the opportunity to go school. In the photo, she is the one holding the sign. For 16 years, Marie has been selling foodstuffs such as oil, pepper, and seasonings at Congo Town, in the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She has good relationships with her customers whenever they come to buy, which keeps them returning. Marie plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more oil, pepper, and seasonings. Her goal is to grow her business into a shop. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more oil, pepper, and seasonings

loans.name: Seline

texts.en:
Seline A. A. is taking a loan of Kes 20,000 to buy kale, tomatoes and onions to grow her business. The business is located at Nyamasaria market in Kisumu. Nyamasaria is a new open-air market which has a lot of potential for growth.

Seline has been selling vegetables to the local people for the last seven years. She plans to grow these vegetables herself to sell, which would be much cheaper than buying and reselling them.

Seline is thirty-five years old, is married, and has five children to whom she hopes to give education to university level. She describes herself as hardworking and humble.

loans.use: To buy more kale, tomatoes and onions

loans.name: Ebenezer #3 Group

texts.en: Standly W. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called “Ebenezer #3”. He is 23 years old, is single, and has no children. He is presently a 9th grade student seeking higher education. In the photo, he is the one holding the sign. For three years, Standly has been selling apples at Broad Street, opposite Sports Commission, in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. The placement of his goods attracts customers and keeps them returning. He started by selling biscuits around downtown Monrovia, but now has a table to sell on. Standly purchases goods with United States dollars and sells in Liberian dollars and this is a problem for his business because of the foreign exchange rate. Standly plans to use his 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 44,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more apples to improve his business. His goal is to grow his business into a shop. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more apples to improve his business

loans.name: Victo

texts.en: Victo is a single mother of three children and her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she stays with five people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Victo takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, rent, school fees and feeding the family. Victo owns a stall in Nakawa Market selling second hand clothes. She sells to all categories of people at retail only. She works seven days a week. Victo receives at least 20 customers a day. She has been in this business for six years and her business challenges include seasonality and the rainy season because she works from an open place. She has been with MCDT for four years, servicing her 12th loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to start going directly to Mombasa to import second hand clothes. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional commodities for her business

loans.name: Cheick Oumar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Cheick Oumar Sangaré est un homme marié de 43 ans  qui est père de 4 enfants. Il vit dans une famille nucléaire avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son feu père  à Bougouni dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord.
Après avoir passé quelques années à l’école moderne, il décida de  l’abandonner  pour mener des activités économiques.
Il fit d’abord le berger puis la commercialisation des bœufs  mais sans succès. Il décida finalement d’apprendre auprès de son oncle l’achat et la vente des chemises, des chaussures, et des articles de fête. Avec une expérience de plus de 12 années, il maîtrise son activité et est très sollicité.
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus plus en nombreuse, il décida rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son  quatrième prêt individuel. Tous les  prêts précédent ont été correctement remboursés.
Il compte utiliser ce prêt  pour acheter,  des douzaines de chemises, des paires de chaussures et divers articles de fête.
Il s’approvisionne à Lomé. Ses clients sont composés d’hommes et des femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000FCFA qui servira à  agrandir sa boutique et subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Cheick Oumar Sangaré is a married, 43-year-old man who is the father of four children. He lives in a nuclear family with his wife and children at his late father's home in Bougouni, in the Hérémakono Nord quarter. After having spent several years at the modern school, Cheick Oumar decided to leave and start a business. He was primarily a shepherd who sold commercial beef, but was unsuccessful. He finally decided to learn his uncle's business of buying and selling shirts, shoes, and celebratory clothing. With more than 12 years of experience, he teaches his trade to others and is often solicited for his services. In order to better meet the demands of his clients, Cheick Oumar decided to join Soro Yiriwaso. He is on his fourth individual loan. All of his previous loans have been repaid in full. He plans on using this loan to purchase dozens of shirts, pairs of shoes, and diverse holiday clothing. He gets his stock in Lomé. His clients are both male and female. With this loan, he foresees making a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA which will serve to grow his boutique and contribute to his family's needs.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of diverse articles of clothing

loans.name: Mawuena

texts.fr: Cet  homme de 36 ans est marié et père d’un enfant ; afin de pouvoir subvenir convenablement au besoin de sa famille, il s’est lancé en 2002 dans la vente de chaussures qu'il expose au bord de la route pour attirer le regard des passants. Il s’approvisionne au marché local de hedzranawoé. Faisant face à une baisse de son stock de marchandises, il souhaiterait gonfler son stock pour mieux satisfaire ses clients raison pour laquelle  il demande un premier prêt pour l’achat de 40 chaussures.
texts.en:
This 36 year-old man is a married father with one child. Seeking to provide for his family he began to sell shoes for a living in 2002; he sells these at the roadside in order to capture passing trade, and sources his goods from the local market at Hedzranawoé. He is facing a stock shortage and would like to increase his stock levels to satisfy his customers' demands. For this reason he is seeking his first loan to buy 40 pairs of shoes.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of shoes

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is married with three children and her children go to school. She rents a two- room house where she stays with five people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Joyce doesn’t take care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, rent, school fees and feeding the family. Joyce owns a ladies salon in Kampala city and works on all types of hair whether plaiting, relaxing weaving etc and works at retail only. She works six days a week. Joyce receives at least five customers a day. Joyce has been in this business for three years and her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She has been with MCDT for a few years servicing her 12th loan. She wants to use this loan to increase her stock of weaves, relaxers and braids.  She hopes to see her business grow bigger and own a bridal salon. She joined MCDT because she wanted her business to grow.

loans.use: To buy more weaves, hair relaxers and braids

loans.name: Te Agbo

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce  en détails d’appareils électroniques, il a une clientèle de taille composée de toutes personnes. Il n'a plus de stock de marchandises alors qu'il fait face à une demande élevée, il doit rehausser son stock pour satisfaire convenablement ses clients. Il sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour l’achat de divers appareils électroniques, il s’approvisionne au port autonome de Lomé.
 Il est marié et père de 02 enfants, le revenu de son commerce lui permet de subvenir aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman’s income generating activity is the retail of electronic appliances. He has a sizable clientele made up of all sorts of people. He does not have any merchandise in his stock while he is facing a high demand. He must increase his stock to properly satisfy his customers. He is requesting a first loan from WAGES to purchase electronic appliances. He gets his goods from the independent port of Lomé. He is married and the father of two children. The income from his business allows him to provide for the family’s expenses.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of electronic  appliances

loans.name: Akoébenoude

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, elle a une expérience de plus de 4 ans dans ce commerce ce qui lui a permis de bien maîtriser ce commerce. Son stock actuel ne lui permet plus de satisfaire tous ses clients, elle veut augmenter son stock raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour l’achat de 20 bidons d’huile végétale et divers.
Elle est mariée et mère de 1 enfant, le revenu de son commerce lui permet de contribuer financièrement aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
This lady has an income-generating activity selling general grocery products. She has more than four years experience in this business, which has allowed her to master it well. Her current stock is not sufficient to satisfy all her customers and she would thus like to increase it. It is for this reason that she is requesting a first loan from WAGES in order to buy 20 containers of vegetable oil and other miscellanous products. She is married and mother to one child. The income from her business allows her to contribute financially to her family's expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of general grocery products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia is widowed with five children. Her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she stays with seven people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Sylvia takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. Resty owns a store where she fries samosas, mandazi and donuts. She doesn’t pay rent for her  because she works from her home and sells to all categories of people at retail only. She works seven days a week. Resty receives at least 25 customers a day. She has been in this business for five years and her business challenges include seasonality and the rainy season because she works from an open place. She has been with MCDT for a few years servicing her 11th loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more cooking oil, baking flour, cowpeas and firewood. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and own  distributing to different school canteens. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. 

 .

loans.use: To buy more baking flour, cooking oil and cowpeas

loans.name: Pilly

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 38 years old Pilly Rashid L. from Coastal Region She is single with 2 children, between the ages of 12 and 21. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependants because are orphan 
Pilly has been running a snack sales since 2004. Client’s business is bites seller, this is the business where by woman are  used to sell snacks such as cakes, bun, chapati etc to their neighborhood when they take tea or coffee in the morning.
She works at the business for 1-4 hours per day, 6 days per week Pilly is requesting a loan of 300,000 TSH in order to buy additional wheat flour, cooking oil and other ingredients for her business. In the future, she plans to start another business. Pilly thanks you for your support!
ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy additional wheat flour, maize flour for her business.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. N. is fifty years old. She is married and has two children aged twenty-five and twenty-three years old.

Rose’s business is located at Katito in Kisumu. Kisumu is known as the Lake Region in Kenya and there is a lot of fish that comes from that area for local consumption and even export. Her business is well known by the name Rozy Hotel. Although it is called a hotel, it is a restaurant and it serves the local people.

Rose has been running this business for the last eleven years and she says that, although the business is good and profitable, there are so many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers that her customers are not loyal as they are spoilt for choice.

Rose is using her loan of Kes 60,000 to buy cooking flour, cooking oil, rice, baking flour and beans to make food to sell. She is very hardworking.

loans.use: To buy more cooking flour, cooking oil, rice, baking flour and beans

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en: N. Cissy is a resident of Kawempe Lugoba near St. Mark Clinic. She has a clothing business and she is a farmer in the village. She has been in business for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase clothes (sportswear) from Kampala shops for her shops in Kalerwe. She wants to expand her business of selling sportswear. She is a promising business lady whose dream is traveling to Nairobi to purchase her goods at a subsidized price.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Anasthasie

texts.fr: M. Anasthasie est née le 01 Mai 1975 à Agonlin, dans le département du Zou au Bénin. Mariée à YEMIHIN Pierre, un maçon, Anasthasie est mère de quatre enfants. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de leurs enfants. Il y a environs 10 ans que Anasthasie s'est installée à Gbodjè dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure les différentes charges de la famille. Anasthasie n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Depuis 4 ans, Anasthasie vend divers articles (conserves de tomate et de sardine, lait, pâtes alimentaires, savons, piles, bougies, poissons frits) ainsi que des condiments de sauce dans une barraque à son domicile. Anasthasie s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et au marché de Cococodji. Anasthasie a obtenu une fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Dans le but d'élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Anasthasie sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Anasthasie M. was born on 1st May 1975 in Agonlin, in the "département" (administrative district) of Zou in Bénin. Married to Pierre YEMIHIN, a builder, Anasthasie is mother to four children. The couple have another child in their care, apart from their own children. For around ten years Anasthasie has been settled with her children and husband in Gbodjè in the municipaility of Abomey Calavi. The couple shares responsibility for the various family expenses. Anasthasie never went to school. For the past four years she has been selling from a stand in her home various items (cans of tomatoes and sardines, milk, pasta, soap, batteries, candles, fried fish), as well as condiments for sauces. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market, and at the market in Cococodji. Anasthasie has had one loan from ALIDé which she repaid in full. With a view to raising the level of her activity and in order to respond better to her customers' demands, she is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of four cartons of pasta, five cartons of cans of milk, cans of tomatoes and sardines etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional medicine in bulk.

loans.name: George Kimani

texts.en:
George is 36 years old, married and a father of two boys: Paul and Lewis. He has a food kiosk in Uthiru Trading Center where he sells ready-cooked foods like fries, chicken, rice and others. This is his primary business and he has been doing this for a number of years now. His wife Lucy helps him at the food kiosk.

He learned about KADET through a neighbor who was already a member. This is his third loan with KADET.  With this loan, George plans to buy a bigger cooker so that he can be more efficient in delivering his food services to his customers.

loans.use: To buy a bigger cooker for his food kiosk

loans.name: Noelie

texts.fr: C. Noelie est née le 26 Décembre 1984 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Noelie vit depuis près de 20 ans à Cococodji dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Noelie a un enfant qui est scolarisé, mais Noelie ne vit plus avec son mari. Noelie supporte seule les charges de son enfant. Noelie a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Il y a environs cinq ans que Noelie  mène comme activité, la vente de "pur water" (emballages d'eau) dans sa boutique à Cococodji. De façon secondaire, Noelie vend des cartes de recharges téléphoniques dans sa boutique. Noelie s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et au marché de Cococodji. C'est la première fois que Noelie sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un prêt, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Noelie C. was born on 26th December 1984 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. She has lived for almost 20 years in Cococodji in the municipality of Abomey Calavi. Noelie has one child who is at school, but she no longer lives with her husband.She has sole responsibility for all expenses relating to her child. Noelie left school during secondary level. For around five years she has had an activity selling "pur water" (packs of water) in her shop in Cococodji. As a secondary activity she sells recharge cards for telephones in her shop. Noeli gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market, and also at the market in Cococodji. It is the first time she has requested a loan from ALIDé, in order to strengthen her business and satisfy her customers more readily.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 150 packs of water and 20 telephone recharge cards

loans.name: Lucy Wangechi

texts.en:
Lucy operates a school in Ndumbuini Trading Center that has all lower primary classes established. She is still constructing it bit by bit, as she gets funds. She targets children from the neighborhood and this has been her primary business, which she has been doing for the last four months. Ndubuini area has a high population, most of whom are low-income earners.

She was introduced to KADET by an existing member and this is her first loan from KADET. She has not borrowed from other financial institutions apart from KADET. She will use the loan advance to buy more desks for the school and also construct a few more classrooms in order to accommodate more students. 

She wants to buy a truck and complete building the school and equipping it with all the required equipment.

loans.use: To build more iron sheet class rooms, amounting to KSHS 40,000, and Buy desks for KSHS 20,000

loans.name: Jared

texts.en: Jared O. O. is forty and married with six children. His business is in a busy market in an up-coming middle-class estate known as Mambo leo in Kisumu. He makes and sells suits, dresses, and uniforms to the local people including the parents of school children. Jared says that business is good but there is a lot of competition. He is using his loan of Kes.60,00 to buy materials to make more clothes to sell. He hopes to build his own store and also to give his children a quality education to the university level.

loans.use: materials

loans.name: Julia Kyomuhendo

texts.en: Julia is a single mother of one child and her child goes to school. She rents a two-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Julia takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, rent, school fees and feeding the family. Julia owns a restaurant selling all types of snacks like chips, chaps, chapatti, macaroni etc. She works seven days a week. Julia receives at least 30 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail.  Julia has been in this business for four years and her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She has been with MCDT for a few years servicing her 10th loan.  She wants to use this loan to increase her stock of food for her restaurant including bags of Irish potatoes, cooking oil, baking flour, beef and liver. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and own a big hotel. She joined MCDT because she could easily access loans so that she could solve her needs.

loans.use: To buy more irish potatoes, cooking oil, baking flour, beef and liver

loans.name: Agbidi Séraphine

texts.fr: H. Agbidi Séraphine est née le 27 Novembre 1975 à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique. Mariée et mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, Séraphine vit depuis cinq ans avec sa famille au quartier Dogoudo à Allada. Le couple a deux autres enfants à leurs charges. Séraphine vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille. Séraphine n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Depuis 15 ans environs, Séraphine mène comme activité la vente de bouillie de maïs accompagnée de beignets de blé à Allada. C'est également à Allada que Séraphine s'approvisionne. Séraphine avait déjà obtenu de ALIDé, trois crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Séraphine désire renforcer un peu plus son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C'est ce qui l'amène à solliciter auprès de ALIDé, un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
Agbidi Séraphine H. was born 27 November 1975 in Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic. She is married and the mother of four children, all in school. For the past five years Séraphine has been living with her family in the Dogoudo borough of Allada. The couple care for two other children, and Séraphine helps her husband in handling the family’s various expenses. Séraphine has never been to school. For about 15 years, she has sold cornmeal mush accompanied by wheat fritters in Allada, where she also gets her supplies. She has already been granted three loans from ALIDé, all of which have been repaid in full. Now Séraphine wishes to strengthen somewhat more her business and increase customer satisfaction. This is why she is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy one bag of wheat flour, one basin of corn, and 1/2 bag of powdered sugar.

loans.name: Hajjarah

texts.en: Hajjarah A. is a promising businesswoman and a resident of Bukoto Mulimila Zone. She owns a retail shop at her home. She has operated her business for almost eight years. She is using the loan to purchase retail shop items such as sugar, packed milk, soda, eggs, safi juice, salt, soap, flour, rice, and so forth to sell. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to improve on her rental houses to generate more income.

loans.use: To purchase more items for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional clothes to sell

loans.name: Vignigbédé

texts.fr: Née le 05 Octobre 1961 à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique, Z. Vignigbédé est mère de cinq enfants tous scolarisés, dont quatre sont encore à sa charge. Vignigbédé est une veuve qui vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule leurs différentes charges. Il y a près de dix ans que Vignigbédé s'est installée au quartier Dogoudo à Allada. Vignigbédé n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins, Vignigbédé vend des colas et de l'huile de palme depuis 35 ans. Vignigbédé s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et à Ayou au Bénin. Mais Vignigbédé vend ses produits à Allada, Houègbo et à Sékou, dans le département de l'Atlantique. Vignigbédé a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Vignigbédé sollicite un quatrième prêt, afin d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born 5 October 1961 in Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic. Vignigbédé Z. is married and the mother of five children, all having attended (or still attending) school, and of whom four are still under her care. Vignigbédé is a widow who lives alone with her children and is their sole support. She settled some ten years ago in the Dogoudo borough of Allada. Vignigbédé has never been to school. To meet her needs, she has been selling cola nuts and palm oil for 35 years. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market, and from Ayou in Benin, but sells her products in Allada, Houègbo and Sékou, in the Department of the Atlantic. Vignigbédé has already been granted three loans from ALIDé, all of which have been repaid in full. She is now requesting a fourth loan to increase her stock supply and better meet customer demand.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy two basins of cola nuts and five containers of palm oil

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en: Geoffrey A. O. is 31 and married with three children. His wife is a tailor. Geoffrey's business is in a busy market in Kakamega where he has done shoe repair for the last twelve years. He says business is good but there is a lot of competition meaning less work. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy nails, thread, and tires to do shoe repair and expand his business. Geoffrey repairs shoes using tires and, in Kenya, men often wear sandals made from tires. He describes himself as hardworking and hopes one day to have a shoe store.

loans.use: To buy tires, nails, and thread for shoe repair.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Business Friends Group

texts.en:
Esther Kings, holding the sign, is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Business Friends. She is 43 years old, single and has five children aged 7 to 28 and also cares for a sibling. She did not have the opportunity to go to school due to family responsibilities. For 11 years, Esther has been selling cooked food at the E.L.W.A Junction in Paynesville, Liberia. She presents her food well which keeps customers returning. Esther plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy rice, oil, and seasonings. Her goal is to send her children to school and to build a house.

About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, with an emphasis on women.

loans.use: To buy rice, oil, and seasonings.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is a single mother of five children and her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she stays with seven people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Agnes takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, rent, school fees and feeding the family. Agnes owns a stall selling all types of food like bananas, sweet potatoes, cassava and yellow bananas. She sells to all categories of people at retail only. She works six days a week. Agnes receives at least 15 customers a day. Agnes has been in this business for many years and her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She has been with MCDT for a few years servicing her 12th loan.  She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying more bunches of bananas, bags of cassava, sweet potatoes, yellow bananas, tomatoes and onions. She is hoping to see her business grow bigger and start going directly to farmers. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cassava, sweet potatoes, yellow bananas, etc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is widowed with seven children and all her children go to school. She owns a six-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Catherine doesn’t take care of any additional family members. The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Catherine owns a stall selling passion fruits and oranges in Bwaise market. She works five days a week. Catherine receives at least 30 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Christine has been in this business for 10 years. Prior to this business, she was a poultry farmer. Her business challenges include seasonality.  Catherine has been with MCDT for six years servicing her 10th loan.  She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying bags of oranges and passion fruit. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start going directly to farmers.

loans.use: To buy more bags of oranges and passion fruit

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°4 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
C’est ainsi que le sous groupe Femmes Commerçantes N°4  est composé de Madame Fatoumata T.  la présidente, Madame Aïssatou W. trésorière, toutes deux vendeuses de tissus, de Madame Rokhaya F. vendeuse de légumes, Madame Aminata D. et Madame Ndeye  Khady D. qui vendent respectivement des poissons fumés et des poissons séchés.Madame la présidente Fatoumata T. commerce le tissu wax et basin depuis 6 ans. Elle s'approvisionne en dehors du Sénégal en Rosso à la Mauritanie. De temps en temps, Madame T. diversifie son commerce avec l'achat et la vente d'arachide grillé dans son quartier à Grand Thiès. Agée de 42 ans, Madame Fatoumata T. est mariée et mère de 3 enfants âgés respectivement de 13 ans, 8 ans et 5 ans.
texts.en:
As its name suggests, Femmes Commerçantes is a network of businesswomen, It is based at Grand Thiès and was created in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, its current president. She got the idea of forming the network after participating in a training session run by Oxfam at Thiès, in which she became familiar with group organization and running a business. The members of the group are dedicated to what they do, and meet together once a month. Over and above membership dues, each of them pays 200 FCFA a month into a group operating fund. Looking for financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. The network is divided into 19 subgroups of five people so that financing can be better handled. Each subgroup has its own president and treasurer. They now seek, for the second time, a loan of 100,000 FCFA per member or 500,000 FCFA for each subgroup, to grow their various activities. The members repay their loans to the president and the treasurer, Ms. Coumba Seck. They, in turn, are responsible for repaying U-IMCEC. According to the president, the group’s praiseworthy objective is to fight family poverty. The subgroup Femmes Commerçantes N° 4 consists of the president Ms. Fatoumata T., the treasurer Ms. Aïssatou W. (both retailers of clothing fabric), Ms. Rokhaya F. a vendor of vegetables, Ms. Aminata D. who sells smoked fish, and Ms. Ndeye Khady D. who sells dried fish. The president Fatoumata T. has been selling Wax and Basin types of clothing fabric for the past six years. She gets her supplies outside Senegal, from Rosso in Mauritania. From time to time she varies her business by retailing roasted peanuts in her neighborhood in Grand Thiès. She is 42 years old, married and the mother of three children aged 13, 8, and 5 years.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: get supplies of merchandise

loans.name: Adinsi

texts.fr: Cette femme est une femme mariée, elle est mère de 5 enfants et vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de Bè kpota qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé. Elle est revendeuse de produits d’alimentation générale et exerce ce commerce dans sa propre boutique qu’elle a appelé « Ets KANGO & FRERES ». Sa  clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. Actuellement son stock de marchandises est en baisse, elle souhaite se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de divers produits d’alimentation générale afin de gonfler son stock.
texts.en:
This woman is married and the mother of five children. She lives with her family in Bèkpota, which is a borough in the periphery of Lomé. She retails general food products in her own store she named “Ets Kango et Frères” (Kango & Bros. Cy). Her customers can be anyone and everyone. Her supplies are decreasing and she needs to replenish her stock, which is why she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy an assortment of general food products.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy general food products

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Thompson S., holding the sign, is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God Is Able. He is 52 and married with five children aged 7 to 30. He could not continue his education through 12th grade due to financial problems. For more than two years, Thompson has sold goods such as batteries, soap, and toothpaste in a shop at the Gbengbar Town in Paynesville, Liberia. He has a nice way with customers and sells goods that they need which keeps them returning. He started selling when he lost his job due to the civil crisis. Shortage of capital to improve his business is Thompson's main problem. He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy batteries, soap and toothpaste. His goal is to have a very large business, educate his children, and give his family a good future.

About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To build up his inventory.

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°5 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Pour le cinquième sous groupe (Femmes Commerçante N°5), il est composé de :
-	Madame Yacine S.. Cette femme est la présidente de ce sous groupe, elle est née en 1962. Elle vend au marché depuis 17 ans des poissons séchés, de l’huile de palme et des tissus. Madame Yacine S. est mariée et mère d'un seul enfant âgé de 26 ans. Elle s'active, dit-elle, pour combattre l'oisiveté et régler ses besoins et ceux familiaux. Avec ce crédit, elle compte compléter son budget d'approvisionnement.
-	Madame Mbery  D. qui place divers produits (arachide….) à ses clients qui sont au marché. Elle est dans cette activité depuis 5 ans.
-	Madame Ngousane N.  qui s’active depuis 4 ans dans la vente de fruits en face de l’hôpital régional de Thiès
-	Madame Amy T. vendeuse de niébé (haricot local), du mil et de l’arachide chez elle depuis 4 ans
-	Et Madame Amy D.  qui loue des chaises et bâches pendant des cérémonies. Elle compte  avec sa part du prêt augmenter  son actif en quantité en achetant d’autres chaises

loans.use: strengthen their business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more items to sell in her small store

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is married with six children and all her children go to school. She owns a six-room house where she stays with seven people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Christine doesn’t take care of any additional family members.  The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Christine owns a retail shop selling all types of merchandise like sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil and bread. She works six days a week. Christine receives at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Christine has been in this business for two years. Prior to this business, she was a tailor in Kawala. Her business challenges include seasonality.  Christine has been with MCDT for six years servicing her 12th loan. Before she was dealing in clothes in Kampala city. She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and loaves of bread. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy salt, sugar and soap

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more beer and soda.

loans.name: Corazón De Jesús Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Corazón D. Jesús, inicia su primer ciclo con 10 socias.
Las socias son D. la Comunidad D. Paccha, Distrito D. Vinchos, Provincia D. Huamanga, la población se dedica a la producción pecuaria y agricultura D. cereales en especial.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. animales, cereales, abarrotes en general, crianza D. animales y la agricultura.
Como es el Caso D. la Señora. Maura que es casada y tiene 2 hijos, Maura tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, además Maura venD. productos Omnilife que ofrece a amigos y familiares, sus productos los compra en la ciudad D. Ayacucho, el préstamo que obtendrá será invertido en la compra D. arroz, azúcar. Los sueños D. Maura son mejorar su negocio y ahorrar para la educación D. sus hijos.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 200 soles, 300 soles, 600 soles, haciendo un total D. 9,900 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
The Corazón D. Jesús (Heart of Jesus) Communal Bank began its first loan cycle with 10 members. All are from the Community of Paccha, Vinchos District, Huamanga Province. The local population is dedicated to producing livestock and, especially, cereal agriculture. The members operate different businesses, such as selling animals, cereals, and groceries in general, agriculture and raising animals. Such is the case of Mrs. Maura, who is married and has 2 children. Maura has a store in her house and sells groceries in general. In addition, Maura sells Omnilife products to friends and family members. She buys her products in the city of Ayacucho. Her loan will be invested in buying rice and sugar. Maura dreams of improving her business and saving for the education of her children. The members need different loan amounts like 200 Sols, 300 Sols, 600 Sols, resulting in a total of 9,900 Sols in loans in this communal bank.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING RICE AND SUGAR TO SELL

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita M. lives the village of Capinona, Cabanglasan Bukidnon. She is 42 years old, married and has three grown children. To make a living, she runs a sari-sari (or variety) store where her most popular items are shampoo, dairy products, biscuits, soap and toothpaste. Pacita has owned her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month from her work.

Last year, Pacita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. She used this loan to buy additional products to sell, and has applied for a new loan of 8,000 PHP to restock her store. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to support her family. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita A. lives in the village of Cabuan, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Angelita owns a store where she sells coconut husks (copras) and charcoal. She has been in this business for more than four years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Angelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP to buy additional products to sell, and plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to educate her children and improve her family's life. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is widowed with five children and all her children go to school. She owns a four-room house where she stays with seven people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Ruth takes care of additional family members.  The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Ruth owns grocery shop selling cold drinks and edibles. She works six days a week. Ruth receives at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Ruth has been in this business for 30 years and her business challenges include the rainy season because she works from a muddy place and seasonality. Ruth has been with MCDT for six years servicing her 14th loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy crates of soda, passion fruit, boxes of minerals water and other juices plus cakes and donuts. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start a mini supermarket.

loans.use: To buy more soda, passion fruit and mineral water

loans.name: Femmes Commerèantes N°6 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Pour  les Femmes Commerçantes N°6, elles sont dirigées par Madame Bousso D. âgée de 43 ans et mère de 7 enfants qui vend depuis 5 ans des légumes, arachide, poissons séchés, huile de palme. La trésorière est Madame Moussou C. vendeuse d’huile de palme et poissons séchés depuis 4 ans au marché Grand Thiès. Les autres membres sont composés de Madame Oumy G. qui vend du riz, mil et de l’huile, Madame Soda Lèye vendeuse de poissons frais et de Madame Coumba F.  qui vend des légumes
texts.en:
The group Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) as the name suggests is a network of women who are active in trade. It is based in Grand Thies and was created in 1992 by Maty Niakh, who is the current president of the network. The president had this idea after receving a training from the NGO Oxfam in Thies. She is also trained in group management, business administration, etc. Network members are extremely dedicated and meet once a month. Beside a membership fee to the group, each member is required to contribute monthly with 200 CFA to a solidarity fund. Wishing to finance themselves, they decided to join U-IMCEC. Thus, their network has splitted into 19 groups of 5 people each, for a better use of funding. They request a second loan of 100 000 FCFA per member, which is 500 000 FCFA per sub-group, to develop their various activities. However, the contributions are paid to the President, assisted by the Treasurer of the group, Ms. Seck Coumba during their monthly meetings and they are responsible to refund U-IMCEC. The network, accordng to the president, has only one noble goal: to fight family poverty. The network currently has 19 subgroups, each with a chairman and a treasurer. F.C. No. 6, is chaired by Mrs. Bousso D., who is 43 years of age and mother of 7 children; she has been selling vegetables, peanuts, dried fish and palm oil for five years . The Treasurer is Mrs. C. Moussou, who has been selling palm oil and dried fish for four years at the market place in Thies. The other members are Ms. Oumy G., who sells rice, millet and oil, Ms. Soda L., who sells fresh fish and Ms. Coumba F. who sells vegetables.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies

loans.name: Chrispine

texts.en:
Chrispine has a tailoring business in Kariokor, a very busy estate and market in Nairobi near the city center. This is his primary business, which he has been doing for a while now. His wife, Amoko, operates a salon. Together, they have six children who are in school.

Chrispine was introduced to KADET by an existing member and this is his fourth loan with KADET. He has not borrowed from other financial institutions, apart from KADET. He will use the loan advance to buy more rolls of material (cloth) and he also aspires to open a café. This will cost him about KES40,000. With the balance of the loan he will buy the tailoring material.

His hopes and desires are to diversify his business buy opening the food café so that he can increase his daily income. With this, he will be able to give his family a better life.

loans.use: He wants to buy clothing materials, such as bolts of cloth, and he wants to open a cafe.

loans.name: Akoélé

texts.fr:
En 2003, cette femme s’est lancée dans le commerce  de pagnes, elle exerce ce commerce près du marché local du port autonome de Lomé vu qu’il existe peu de revendeuse de pagnes dans ce marché, ainsi elle arrive à réaliser de grosses recettes. Elle veut augmenter son stock de marchandises raison pour laquelle, elle sollicite auprès de WAGES son premier crédit pour l’achat de 12 pagnes hitarget et de 10 pagnes phoénix.
Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants.
texts.en:
In 2003 this lady began trading "pagnes" (West African colourful fabric), and she carries out this business near the local market in the independent port of Lomé. Since there are very few retailers of "pagnes" in this market, she manages to procure a significant income. She would like to increase her stock of goods and for this reason she is requesting her first loan from WAGES to buy 12 Hitarget "pagnes" and 10 Phoenix "pagnes". She is married and mother to three children.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of "pagnes"

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita B. is from the village of Capiponan, Cabanglasan Bukidnon. She is 46 years old. Mercedita is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Mercedita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling a variety of different products in the local community. Mercedita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mercedita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercedita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & was used towards working capital. Mercedita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Mercedita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy equipment for keeping and carrying milk

loans.name: Grecelda

texts.en:
Grecelda B. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old. Grecelda is married and has 3 school-aged children. Grecelda owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Grecelda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which is about $49 US, every month for these activities.

In 2010, Grecelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Grecelda is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Grecelda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family and support education of children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Angella

texts.en: Angella is married with six children. Two of the children go to school and the other four are finished school. She rents a two-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Angella take care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, rent, school fees and feeding the family. Angella owns a restaurant selling all types of food ranging from traditional food to take-out. She works seven days a week. Angella receives at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Angella has been in this business for 10 years and her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She has been with MCDT for a few years servicing her 10th loan.  She wants to use this loan to increase her stock of food for her restaurant, buy a big saucepan and pay school fees for her children. She is hoping to see her business grow bigger and own a big hotel. She joined MCDT because she could access loans easily.

loans.use: To buy more food for her restaurant and a big saucepan

loans.name: Virgen Inmaculada De Concepcion (Virgin Of The Immaculate Conception) Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Virgen Inmaculada Concepción D. Tambocucho, inicia su primer ciclo con 10 socias.
Las socias son D. L. Comunidad D. Tambocucho, L. población se dedica a L. crianza D. animales y L. agricultura.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como L. venta D. animales, cereales, abarrotes en general, crianza D. animales y L. agricultura.
Como es el Caso D. L. Señora. Teodora que es soltera y no tiene hijo, Teodora tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, además venD. animales menores, quesos que compra en su comunidad y también se dedica a L. agricultura, el préstamo que obtendrá será invertido en L. compra D. quesos que venderá en L. ciudad D. Ayacucho. Los sueños D. Teodora son que sus hermanos menores sean profesionales.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 100 soles, 200 soles, 1000 soles, haciendo un total D. 3,500 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
The community bank called Virgin of the Immaculate Conception in Tambocucho began its first loan cycle with 10 members. The members are from the community of Tambocucho, and this population raises animals and works in agriculture. The members have different businesses, such as selling animals, grains, and groceries, raising animals, and working in agriculture. Description of the case of Miss Teodora: she is single and does not have children. She has a store in her house where she sells general groceries. She also sells small animals and cheese that she buys in her community, and she works in agriculture. The loan that she will receive will be invested in the purchase of cheese that she will sell in the city of Ayacucho. Teodora’s dreams are that her younger brothers have professional careers. The members need different amounts of loans such as 100 soles, 200 soles, 1000 soles, giving a total of 3,500 soles of loans in the community bank.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cheese

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional cloth for her business

Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette femme est une vendeuse d’huile de palme, pâte d’arachide, poissons séchés, pommes de terre et oignons depuis 2004. Mariée et mère de 2 enfants âgés respectivement de 16 et de 13ans, Madame Aminata Dème compte danzs cette activité pour régler ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants. Elle est dans ce sous groupe avec Madame Mame Khary N., la trésorière qui vend des légumes au niveau du marché grand Thiès,  Madame Adama L.  couturière, elle achéte  des tissus les confectionne et les place à ses clients, Madame Penda G. qui fait le commerce ambulant des poissons séchés et Madame Bousso Guèye qui vend de la pâte d’arachide et huile de palme au marché Okass de Thiès
texts.en:
The Femmes Commerçantes (F.C., literalL. "Trading Women") grouping is, as its name indicates, a network of women who are active traders. It is based in Grand Thiès and was created in 1992 by Mrs. Maty Niakh, the current president of the network. She had this idea following a training course she was given by the charitable organisation, OXFAM, in Thiès. She is familiar with managing a group, entrepreneurship etc. The members of the network are extremeL. committed and meet up once a month. On top of the group membership fees they have to pay, each member is obliged to make a monthL. contribution of 200 FCFA to a solidarity fund. As they wanted to be able to finance themselves, they decided to join to U-IMCEC (a Sénégalese association of mutual savings and loans institutions). AccordingL., their network was divided into 19 sub-groups of five members each, in order to take greater advantage of funding. They are requesting a second loan of 100,000 FCFA for each member, that is 500,000 FCFA per sub-group in order to develop their various activities. The payments are made to the president assisted by the treasurer of the group, Mrs. Coumba Seck, during their monthL. meetings, and these two women take on the responsbility in turn to repay U-IMCEC. This network has, according to the president, just one noble objective: to fight poverty among households. CurrentL., it comprises 19 sub-groups, each with their own president and treasurer. The sub-group Femmes Commerçantes No. 7 is managed by Mrs. Aminata Dème, who is 33 years old. This lady has been selling palm oil, peanut butter, dried fish, potatoes and onions since 2004. Married and mother to two children who are 16 and 13 years old respectiveL., Mrs. Aminata Dème carries out this activity in order to provide for her needs and those of her children. She is in this sub-group with Mrs. Mame Khary N., the treasurer who sells vegetables at the market in Grand Thiès, Mrs. Adama L., who is a seamstress and buys fabric which she makes up and sells on to her customers, Mrs Penda G. who is an itinerant vendor selling dried fish and Mrs. Bousso Guèye who sells peanut butter and palm oil at the market in Okass de Thiès.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To develop their business

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina E. is from the village of Alangilan, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 48 years old. Marina is married and has eight school-aged children. Marina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Marina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Marina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. Marina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income of the family and to finance the education of her children.

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°8 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba S., pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Cependant Femmes Commerçantes N°8 est sous la responsabilité de Madame  Khady F.. Cette dernière est âgée de 42 ans et gère une boutique appelée maison bébé. En fait elle vend des habits pour bébés depuis 15 ans. Elle est célibataire et mère d'un seul enfant âgé de 20 ans à ce jour. Cependant Madame Khady F. admet avoir pris en charge les besoins de son enfant avec ses profits du commerce. Elle partage ce sous groupe Femmes Commerçantes N°8 avec Madame Rokhaya N., 53 ans et vendeuse de poissons séchés, Madame Fatou N. vendeuse de glace et de jus locaux, Madame Oumy M. qui fait le commerce ambulant de produits cosmétiques et de Madame Sokhna Aminata S.  qui vend elle aussi du parfum, et thiouraye (encens).
texts.en:
As its name suggests, Femmes Commerçantes is a network of businesswomen. It is based at Grand Thiès and was created in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, its current president. She got the idea of forming the network after participating in a training session run by Oxfam at Thiès, in which she became familiar with group organization and running a business. The members of the group are dedicated to what they do, and meet together once a month. Over and above membership dues, each of them pays 200 FCFA a month into a group solidarity fund. Looking for financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. The network is divided into 19 subgroups of five people so that financing can be better handled. Each subgroup has its own president and treasurer. They now seek, for the second time, a loan of 100,000 FCFA per member or 500,000 FCFA for each subgroup, to grow their various activities. The members repay their loans to the president and the treasurer, Ms. Coumba S.. They, in turn, are responsible for repaying U-IMCEC. According to the president, the group’s praiseworthy objective is to fight family poverty. Femmes Commerçantes N° 8 falls under the responsibility of Mrs. Khady F.. She is 42 years old and runs a shop named “Maison Bébé” (Baby House). She has been selling baby clothes for 15 years. She is unmarried and the mother of one child aged 20. She acknowledges that is the earnings from her commerce that enabled her to take care of her child. She is joined in the Femmes Commerçantes N° 8 group by Mrs. Rokhaya N., a 53-year-old vendor of dried fish; Mrs. Fatou N., vendor of ice cream and local fruit juices; Mrs. Oumy M., an itinerant vendor of beauty products; and Mrs. Sokhna Aminata S., who also sells perfume and thiouraye (incense).

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Santa Rosa de Tambo, inicia su primer ciclo con 10 socias.
Las socias son del Distrito de Tambo, la población se dedica a la ganadería y otras actividades comerciales.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de comida, abarrotes en general, cereales, animales, crianza de animales.
Como es el Caso de la Señora Clementina que es conviviente, tiene 5 hijos, Clementina se dedica a la crianza de ganado vacuno, produce leche y queso, además Clementina compra quesos de sus vecinos, todos los productos los vende en la costa, el préstamo que obtendrá será invertido en la compra de quesos. Los sueños de Clementina son que sus hijos sean profesionales y comprar una casa en la ciudad de Ica.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 100 soles, 300 soles, 600 soles, haciendo un total de 3,800 soles de prestamos en el Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
The Santa Rosa de Tambo Communal Bank began its first loan cycle with 10 members, all from the District of Tambo. The local population is dedicated to cattle raising and other commercial activities. The members are involved in different businesses, including selling meals, general groceries, and raising cereals and animals. A typical case is Mrs. Clementina who lives with her common law partner and has 5 children. Clementina raises cattle and produces milk and cheese. In addition, she buys cheese from her neighbors and sells these products along the coast. Her loan will be invested in buying cheese. Clementina dreams that her children will become professionals, and of buying a house in the city of Ica. The members need different loan amounts, such as 100 sols, 300 sols, 600 sols, for a total of 3,800 sols in loans for this communal bank.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 70-year-old Maria Landi P. from Morogoro. She is widowed with five children between the ages of 12 and 25.

Maria has been running a milk business since 2008. Selling milk is a common business for Tanzanian women, especially Masai women. (the Masai are a tribe found in the northern part of Tanzania). Masai people do not cultivate farms but they own large numbers of cows, goats and sheep. One person can have more than one hundred cows and more than two hundred goats.

They sell their milk in order to get money so that they can buy other food such as maize and beans and to meet other expenses. The milk business is a very successful business because milk is in high demand by many people. Milk contains all the necessary ingredients and vitamins needed for health.

Maria works at her business for 5 to 8 hours per day, 3 days per week, and is assisted by her children. She is requesting a loan of 300,000 Tsh in order to purchase cups, bowls and baskets for her business. In the future, she plans to provide more litres of milk for her customers. Maria thanks you for your support!


About SELFINA: 
SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

texts.en:
Joseph M., holding the sign, is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God’s Power. He is 49 years old and married with nine children between two and 29. He could not continue his education through 10th grade due to his father's death. For 10 years, Joseph has sold goods such as soft drinks, tissues, and soap in a shop at the Gbengbar Town community in Paynesville, Liberia. He sells goods that customers need which keep them returning. He started with 600.00 Liberian Dollars as working capital which he has built up to about 10,000.00 Liberian Dollars. Joseph plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more tissues, soft drinks, and soap. His goal is to have a very large shop with a wider variety of goods to sell.

About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.name: Wastalah

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Wastalah Abdala K. from Morogoro. She is divorced with four children between the ages of 1 and 18.

Wastalah has been running a mama lishe since 2008. A mama lishe (local restaurant or café) in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all-local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour) and plantain (cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.

Wastalah works at her business for 5 to 8 hours per day, 7 days per week, and is assisted by two employees. She is requesting a loan of 200,000 TZS in order to purchase additional wheat flour, maize flour, plates and cups.

In the future, Wastalah plans to do maintenance work on her buildings and to open another business. She thanks you for your support!


About SELFINA: 
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional wheat flour, maize flour, plates and cups
