loans.name: Agness

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 22-year-old Agness Adolf E. from Morogoro. She is married with two children aged 2 and 5. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans. Agness has been running a used-clothing sales business since 2008. 

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Tanzania to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets and in the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because of their low cost, and the general appeal of anything modern.

Agness works at her business for 5 to 8 hours per day, 5 to 8 days per week and is assisted by five people. She is requesting a loan of 250,000 TSH in order to purchase more clothes for her business.

In the future, Agness plans to increase the quantity of her stock. She thanks you for your support!


About SELFINA: 
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.name: Niño Jesus De Ayavi Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Niño Jesús D. Ayavi, inicia su primer ciclo con 13 socias.
Las socias son D. la comunidad D. Ayavi, Distrito D. Ayavi, la población se dedica a la ganadería.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la crianza D. animales, venta D. abarrotes en general y tejido.
Como es el Caso D. la Señora Mónica que es casada, tiene 7 hijos, Mónica venD. comida en su casa, abarrotes en general y en algunas oportunidades se dedica  a tejer chompas, el préstamo que obtendrá será invertido en la compra D. arroz, azúcar. Los sueños D. Mónica son tener un establo con vacas lecheras.
 Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 200 soles, 300 soles, 600 soles, haciendo un total D. 5,900 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Niño Jesús D. Ayavi" started its first loan cycle with 13 members. The members are from the community of Ayavi, in the Ayavi district, where the population mainly works in livestock production. These members work in various businesses such as raising animals, selling groceries, and knitting. Such is the case of Monica, who is married and has 7 children. Monica has a business selling groceries from her house. At times she also knits sweaters. This loan will be invested in the purchase of rice and sugar. Monica dreams of having a stable with milk cows. The members need loans of various amounts such as 200, 300 or 600 Peruvian soles, making a total of 5,900 soles of loans to the communal bank.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy rice and sugar

texts.en:
Vicenta C. is from the village of Barandiaz, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 61 years old, married, and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Vicenta owns and operates a buying and selling business. The main source of income for the business comes from peddling dried fish and some agricultural products, such as banana and coconut fruit, harvested from her small farm and selling it to tourists and local community members. Vicenta has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Vicenta joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Vicenta is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her third from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her house.

loans.name: God's Children Group

texts.en:
Musu S., holding the sign, is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God Children. She is 56 years old and married with six children aged nine to 33. She did not have the opportunity to go to school. For two years, Musu has sold charcoal at the Gbengbar town community in Paynesville, Liberia. She sells dry charcoal that people need which keeps customers returning. She began her business selling 30 bags of charcoal but now sells about 50 bags. Musu plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more charcoal. Her goal is to get more wood to make charcoal.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Azetou

texts.en: Azetou A. is 38 years old, married to a taxi driver, and has three children. She works in the Adidogomé district of Lomé, Togo, selling charcoal, millet, corn and sorgho. She purchases her supplies from the northern part of the country, and then sells her products from home in the south. This will be her third loan with Kiva partner, WAGES, which she will use to resupply her stock. Not only will this loan help support her business, but her family as well.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal, millet, corn and sorgho

loans.name: Porfirio

texts.es:
El señor Porfirio B. M. tiene 3 años de estar laborando Con CEPRODEL-El sauce, como fiador de dichos créditos otorgado a su hijo Ali Josué B. ambos habitan en la comarca el pajarito municipio Achuapa, es por primera vez que el cliente ase solicitud para la compra de 3 terneros para bueyes ya que en su inventario ganadero no tiene. 
El cliente tiene 5 hijos a su cargo 2 están estudiando en la secundaria y los otros trabajan en su finca, cuenta con una propiedad de 80 MZ propia de terreno, donde la desarrolla para la explotación ganadera y agricultura.  
Se dedica a la actividad de agricultura y ganadería la inversión la realizo con el objetivo de tener una mayor fuente de ingresos y mejorar su  trabajo, para así sacarle provecho y abastecer las necesidades de su familia.
texts.en:
Porfirio has been working as a cosigner for his son Ali’s loans through CEPRODEL-El Sauce for the past three years. Both live in the “Pajarito” region of the city of Achuapa. This is his first request and he will use the money to buy three plots of land on which to raise oxen. He has five children, two of whom attend junior high school and the others work his herd. He has his own land which he has developed for raising livestock and for farming. He started farming and raising livestock in order to have a better source of income and improve his work in order to be able to better provide for his family’s needs.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase land to raise oxes

loans.name: Older Wilmer

texts.es:
El señor Older Wilmer P. B. se dedica principalmente a la ganadería tiene 15 años de estar trabajando con este rubro. Es su primer año de estar laborando Con CEPRODEL-El sauce, habita en la comarca san Nicolás municipio Achuapa, se dedica a la actividad de repasto de novillo.
 El crédito solicitado  es para la compro de 2 ternero de desarrollo, tiene su propia finca la inversión la realiza en su propiedad para así sacarle aprovecho y obtener un mayor ingreso y abastecer la necesidades de su familia.
texts.en:
Older primarily raises livestock and has been doing so for the past 15 years. This is his first year working with CEPRODEL-El Sauce. He lives in the San Nicolás region of the city of Achuapa. He raises steers. He will use the money from this loan to buy two plots of land to develop [for raising livestock]. He has his own herd and this investment will allow him to take better advantage of it and improve his income in order to better provide for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Land for raising livestock

loans.name: María Jesus

texts.es:
La señora  María Jesús  A. es socia del Banco Comunal  San Pablo, ella  vive en la comunidad Rumiloma que  se encuentra a unos diez minutos a las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca, localidad que se dedica principalmente  a la agricultura y ganadería,  pero los jóvenes buscan en la ciudad nuevas y mejores oportunidades, nuestra socia se encuentra en 64 años de edad, es viuda hace 13 años porque su difunto esposo bebía en exceso, en su vida conyugal gestó  seis hijos quienes se encuentran de 42, 38, 36, 31, 27, 23 años,  sus cuatro hijos primeros  son casado y viven independientes con sus familias,  y sus dos hijos solteros viven con ella  pero no le ayudan con  los gastos del hogar, se siente muy orgullosa de haber construido su casa que aunque es pequeña es propia.

María Jesús  se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras,  desde su corta edad diez años empezó en ésta labor, trabaja cinco días a la semana  su horario de 8 a.m. hasta las 6 p.m. o según como termine la venta de su producto,  descansa los días martes y jueves.

Se encuentra en su cuarto ciclo en la fundación y los préstamos obtenidos ha invertido en  productos para abastecer su negocio, con el nuevo crédito  va a  comprar  manzanas, naranjas, naranjillas, uvas, acelga, zanahoria, remolacha, entre otras frutas y verduras para abastecer un poco su puesto para ofrecer a sus clientes   ya que éstos productos  se encuentran escasos  muy caros por la sequia que esta atravesando la región, su sueño es contar con buena salud para así seguir trabajando en su puesto de frutas y verduras que es su sustento diario.
texts.en:
María Jesús is a member of the San Pablo community banking group. She lives in the Rumiloma community, found 10 minutes outside of the city of Cuenca, whose primary business is that of farming and raising cattle - but the younger people look to the city for new and better opportunties. Our member is 64 years old, and has been widowed for 13 years. Her late husband drank in excess. She had 6 children who are 42, 38, 36, 31, 27, and 23 years old. Her first four children are married and live on their own with their families. Her two single children live with her, but don't help her with the household expenses. She feels very proud to have built her home, which although small, is her own. María Jesús works selling fruits and vegetables. From the young age of 10, she began this work, working 5 days a week from 8 am - 6 pm, or until she's sold out of her products. She has Tuesdays and Thursdays off. She is now in her 4th cycle with the foundation (ESPOIR) and the with loans she's received, she's invested in products to supply her business. With this new loan, she is going to buy apples, oranges, naranjillas (a citrus fruit from Ecuador), grapes, carrots, beets, among other fruits and vegetables, to supply her fruit stand to offer to her clients, since these scarce products are very expensive due to the the drought that has occurred in this region. Her dream is to remain in good health so that she can continue working in her fruit and vegetable stand which is her daily livelihood.

Translated from Spanish by Kimberly Baker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy apples, oranges, naranjillas, grapes, chard, carrots, beets, etc

loans.name: Sophie

texts.en: Sophie is married with one child and her child goes to school. She owns a two-room house where she stays with five people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Sophie takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, rent, school fees and feeding the family. Sophie owns a bar (pub) in Kanyanya selling all types of beer. She sells to all categories of people at retail only. She works seven days a week. Sophie receives at least 30 customers a day. She has been in this business for four months and her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. Besides this beer business, she also sells plates, glasses and cups. She has been doing this business for years. She has been with MCDT for many years servicing her 14th loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beers and breakables like cups and glasses. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and own a beer depot. Her business challenges include transportation of crates of beer from the depot to her business premises. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women.

loans.use: To buy more beer, glasses, cups and plates

loans.name: Isabel Eusebia

texts.es: A consecuencia de un robo, y la difícil situación que atravesó la familia de Isabel, ella tuvo que apoyar a su esposo con los gastos familiares, empezó haciendo postres como tortas, mazamorras, gelatinas, flan, leche asada y otros postres conocidos que vendía en el kiosco de un colegio aledaño a su vivienda, pero eso no ayudaba mucho con los gastos, así que con el préstamo obtenido comprara menaje y otros utensilios que necesite para apertura un restaurante en su vivienda con el cual pueda lograr mayores ingresos. Ella está muy contenta y tiene muchas expectativas con este nuevo reto.
texts.en:
Because of a robbery and the difficult situation that has occured to the family of Isabel, she had to help her husband with the family expenses. She started making desserts like cake, mazamorras (a kind of corn pudding), gelatins, flan, leche asada ("roasted milk") and other well-known desserts that she sold in a kiosk of a school next to her home. But this hasn't help much with the expenses, which is why with this loan that she receives, she will buy supplies and other utensils that she needs to open a restaurant in her home, with which she'll be able to generate greater income. She is very content and is excited about this new challenge.

Translated from Spanish by Kimberly Baker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of supplies

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva V. is from the village of Casinglot, Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Eva owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing photography services to local community members. Eva has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Eva joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide her services. Eva is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase materials needed to provide her services. This loan will be her second from HSPFI, and she has chosen to borrow the same amount as her first loan cycle. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide her services

loans.name: Melisa

texts.en:
Melisa G. is from the village of Barandiaz, Pangantucan Bukidnon. She is 23 years-old and married with a baby. Melisa owns and operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products such as fish and dried fish in the local community. She also owns a small sari-sari (general) store . Melisa has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melisa joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. Melisa is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Melisa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement the family income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Diombo

texts.en:
Diombo D. is a 58-year-old married woman who is responsible for one child. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois Thiéckène for nine years and has always paid back her loans on time. She runs a little business selling second-hand clothes and hand-dyed cloth known as «thioup». As a side activity, Diombo D. sells palm oil and peanut butter.

Diombo D. wants to use this loan to buy more second-hand clothes as well as peanuts and palm oil.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes, peanuts and palm oil.

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.en: Akouvi D. is 32 years-old. She is married and does not have children. She lives and works in the Adidogomé district of Lomé, Togo selling cell phones and mobile phone accessories. She began this business in 2006 and is requesting her third loan from Kiva partner WAGES. She will use this loan to resupply her stock in order to better serve her customers. By working to keep Togo connected, Mrs. D.’s business will continue to grow.

loans.use: To purchase cell phones and accessories for resale.

loans.name: United Brother Group

texts.en:
Henry S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Brother. He is 26 years old, single and has a 3 years old child. He could not continue his education after high school.

For 5 years Henry has been selling medicated robs, lotion for rashes and other skin problems.He sells adjacent the Ministry Of Finance, in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He sells goods that customers need which keeps them returning.

He started selling with 1,000 LRD as working capital, but now has 15,000 LRD as working capital.

Henry plans to use his portion of the group loan to buy more medical robs to improve his business. His goal is to grow his business to a better size.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Henry is the one holding the sign.


About LEAP

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more medical robs to improve his business.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en: Annet is divorced with children and her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she stays with seven people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Annet takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, rent, school fees and feeding the family. Annet owns a stall selling bananas in Kiwatule and sells to all categories of people at retail only. She works six days a week. Annet receives at least 15 customers a day. Annet has been in this business for many years and her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She has been with MCDT for a few years servicing her eighth loan. She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying more bunches of bananas. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start going directly to farmers. She joined MCDT because she wanted her business to grow and MCDT was working with poor women.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Bernadeth

texts.en:
Bernadeth R. is from the town of Poblacion, Valencia City. She is 46 years-old and married with two adult children.  Bernadeth owns and operates a a specialized buy and sell business selling vegetables and bananas in the local community. Bernadeth has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Bernadeth joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernadeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. Bernadeth is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Bernadeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement the family income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy corn

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta H. is from the village of Casinglot, Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years-old and married with four school-aged children. Julieta owns and operates a sari-sari (general) shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Julieta joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Julieta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Monique

texts.en:
Monique N. is 55 years old, married, and the mother of four children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" in Thiékène for 9 years and has always paid back her loans on time.

She sells various products: clothes and shoes, cosmetics and fruit juice. She has a long experience in her business. This loan will allow her to purchase more of the products that she wants to resell.

loans.use: To buy products to bolster her shop

loans.name: La Inmaculada Concepcion Group

texts.es:
Filomena tiene una tienda en su casa que le permite mantener a sus 3 hijos, aperturo su negocio hace varios años cuando atravesó algunos problemas, L. ventaja que elL. tiene es que pueD. coger algunos productos D. su tienda para preparar sus  alimentos, por otro lado L. desventaja que tiene es que con las ventas obtiene menos ganancia aun así elL. es optimista y tiene muchas ganas D. salir adelante es por eso que el grupo L. escogió como presidenta
Guadalupe apoya a su esposo con L. venta D. gelatinas, chupetes y gaseosas, con los pocos ingresos pueD. aportar con los gastos en casa, el préstamo recibido lo invertirá en comprar más productos para L. preparación D. los mismos, algo que le preocupa es que los productos han subido sus costos y tendrá que invertir más D. lo proyectado. Guadalupe es L. secretaria del grupo.
A nuestra socia Victoria le gusta L. cocina así que por las noches se  dedica a  L. venta D. salchipapas, hamburguesas, gaseosa y café en L. puerta D. su casa, eso L. ayuda para solventar L. educación D. sus 4 hijos.
El grupo es unido y responsable y se dedican a diferentes negocios tales como : pequeñas bodegas, preparación y venta D. dulces, venta D. frazadas, y trabajos comunales en diversas zonas aledañas. Ellas agradecen los préstamos obtenidos.
texts.en:
Filomena has a store in her house, allowing her to also take care of her 3 children while working. She opened her store several years ago, when she was going through some hardships. The advantage of her business is that she has household products in stock that she can use for her own family, but then she doesn't earn as much income from sales. Nevertheless, she is optimistic and dedicated to improving, which is why her group chose her as their president. Guadalupe helps her husband by selling gelatin desserts, lollipops, and sodas. With this modest income she can cover household expenses. The loan she received was invested in the purchase of ingredients for the above products. She is worried because the cost of these products have risen, so she now needs more money than she anticipated. Guadalupe is the group secretary. Victoria likes to cook, so at night she sells salchipapas (french fries and hot dogs), hamburgers, soda and coffee outsiD. her house. This activity helps her put her 4 children through school. The group is unified and responsible. They work in different businesses such as small stores, dessert preparation and sales, blanket sales, and community work in nearby regions. The members are grateful for the loans they have received.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of products and supplies.

loans.name: Adjoa Idé

texts.en: Adjoa Idé E. is 35 years-old. She is married to a pastor and has three children. Mrs. E. works in the Adidogomé district of Lomé, Togo selling jewelry, fabric, purses, and ready-to-wear clothing. She began this business in 2000 and is now requesting her second loan from Kiva partner WAGES. She will use this loan to resupply her stock of jewelry, fabrics and any other products needed to keep her business running smoothly. With your support, Mrs. E.’s business will continue to prosper.

loans.use: To purchase  fabric, jewelry and various other products.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma B. is from the town of Poblacion, Valencia City. She is 50 years old and single. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing shirt-making services to local community members. Emma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Emma joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Emma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Only God Group

texts.en:
Abraham Q. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Only God. He is 81 years old, married, and he has 9 children aged 22 to 62 years old. His responsibilities include 3 siblings. He could not continue his education after 9th grade.

For 5 years Abraham has been selling charcoal at Peace Island in Congo Town in Monrovia, Liberia. Originally he started selling meat but now he is in the charcoal business. He sells his charcoal to customers in a nice manner and at a stable price which keeps them returning.

Abraham plans to use his portion of the group loan to buy more charcoal to sell. His goal is to grow his business to a shop.

In the photo Abraham is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Love Group

texts.en:
Siah G. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Love (in the photo that accompanies this profile, Siah is the one holding the sign). She is 33 years old, single and has a ten-year-old child. She did not have the opportunity to go to school.

For fourteen years Siah has been selling baby things such as baby bottles, diapers and panties at the Rally town market in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She sells good merchandise which keeps customers returning. 

Siah's business started with 3,000 LRD as working capital but now has about 36,000 LRD as working capital. Siah plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more baby bottles, diapers and babies’ panties. Her goal is to grow her business into a shop in the near future.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts an emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more feeding bottles, diapers and babies panties.

loans.name: Marie Augustine

texts.en:
Marie Augustine M. is 46 years old, married and the mother of 14 children. She sells palm oil and citrus juice and raises pigs as a side activity.

Marie Augustine has been a member of the Banc Villageois Thiéckéne for nine years and has always paid back her loans on time. With this loan, she plans to buy pigs and palm oil.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and palm oil.

loans.name: Mayra Mercedes

texts.es:
Mayra S. es socia del Banco Comunal  San Pablo ubicado en la ciudad de Cuenca en la  comunidad de Rumiloma a unos 10 minutos a  las afueras de la urbe,  esta localidad  se caracteriza porque su población se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería mientras que los  jóvenes prefieren migrar a ciudades más grandes dentro del país o fuera de él en  busca de mejores oportunidades para salir adelante junto a sus familias.

Mayra tiene 27 años de edad, se encuentra casada y como fruto de su unión concibió dos  hijos quienes se encuentran de 8 y 4 años, el mayor  estudia en una escuela de la ciudad, su esposo trabaja como albañil,  no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en casa de su hermano.

Este es  su cuarto ciclo trabajando con  préstamos de su banco comunal  incentivada por su mamá,  ella se dedica a la cría de pollos, cuyes, también a la agricultura siembra verduras y le queda tiempo para atender  su tienda de víveres  que tiene hace dos años y su horario de atención es de 6 a.m. hasta las 10 p.m. de domingo a domingo. Con el nuevo crédito que realiza va a  comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, sal,  jabón, y otros víveres para surtir más su tienda.

Tiene como  sueño  llegar a  tener  su casa propia.
texts.en:
Mayra Mercedes is a partner of the San Pablo Community Bank located in the city of Cuenca, in the Rumilona community, which is located 10 minutes from the city center. This locality characterizes itself for the fact that its population is dedicated to agriculture and cattle ranching. The young population prefers to migrate to bigger cities in the country and abroad in search for better opportunities for them and their families. Mayra is 27 years old and is married. During this marriage she conceived two children who are now 8 and 4 years old. The oldest goes to a school in the city. Her husband is a bricklayer. They do not own a house and live with her brother. This is her fourth cycle working with loans from the community bank, due to her mother's incentive. She raises chickens, guinea pigs and also dedicates herself to agriculture by sowing vegetables. She also has time to attend to the general store she has had for two years. Her working hours are from 6am to 10pm Sunday to Sunday. With the new loan she plans to purchase rice, sugar, cooking oil, salt, soap and other provisions to diversify her inventory. Her dream is to one day own her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, sugar, cooking oil, salt, soap and others
